Came here three times when I was living at 1130. Heard so many positive reviews. But for me, Food is not so surprisingly good. Coffee is delicious tho.

This place was pretty good. I wasn't blown away by the food, but it was definitely good breakfast fare. We got here 20 minutes after they opened, and would have had to wait unless we sat at the counter (which we did and that was fine). This place gets a lot of hype, and while the food is good, it's nothing life-changing. Service is pretty good and the staff good-natured. A great place to stop before you head over to the Field Museum or Shedd.

Awesome brunch!!!  I had the Western skillet, which was huuuuuge.  Because I was with my boyfriend and we were sharing, I ordered pancakes as my side.  They were some of the fluffiest, yummiest pancakes I have ever had.  Definitely the best choco chip pancakes ever.   Prices are super reasonable.  Coming from NYC, this was a huge plus!

Just a good place to get a solid breakfast. Bright and spunky decor greets you at the door, idiosyncratic dishware and all. Reminiscent of the old diner style while keeping an open floor plan to keep things breathable. But the service brings you in efficiently to a pleasant booth where they'll offer you coffee or another beverage and let you loose on the menu. Breakfast standards riffed on perhaps unsurprisingly, but well-executed in a way that will probably keep you coming back. Traditional breakfasts with the usual suspects are always good. The huge portions on the Benedicts, Hashes, and Omelettes are very welcome to any breakfast lover. Overall, ya need a good breakfast, ya go to Yolk. There you go.

3.5 stars Yolk was great, fresh, and delicious.....but I'm sorry......... there is just something extra special about Bongo Room that makes me say, "Get your Bongo on at Bongo Room, instead". If you had to choose,  i would select Bongo Room, a restaurant in the Wabash area that serves breakfast and brunch. But, I think the line at Yolk might be less of a wait.
Fantastic brunch food! Pancakes, eggs, crepes, egg sandwich and sausage gravy are just a few of my top favorites! Yolk is my go to brunch place! Never disappointed!
Big space!!  Food was good, service was just okay.  I like the location but I would rather eat at the Bongo Room for brunch.  Overall a good experience and prices are decent.

Loved our meal here!  We were craving a hardy breakfast with eggs, potatoes, sausage, etc. And this was the place!  I got the skillet with sausage and everything was so good! My friend got their Egg Benedict which was good but nothing special. We also got their strawberry orange juice and I thought it was ok.  If hardy breakfast is what you are looking for definitely check this place out. If you want something different on the breakfast menu, not sure if this is the place for that.

Best breakfast we had 2 mornings in Chicago. The place is jammed but the staff moves fast and the wait is minimal. I got the Mediterranean omelette while my boyfriend got the Texas one. It was to die for...both of them. You get a choice of toast or pancakes on the side. No brainer. :)  Two drinks and two meals runs you roughly $30 plus tip. I didn't think it was that bad considering the meal, quality and taste. I was more than OK with this...we loved it so much we will go again the next time we're in town.

Round 3 of South Loop brunch spots took us to Yolk.  We arrived around 9:00 AM on a Sunday and were seated immediately which I was surprised by since we had just walked by a large group of people waiting outside Bongo Room.  The space is super bright & cheery and they have a huge staff working which get your coffee quickly and is quick on refills. I choose the Tuscan Fritatta.  I loved the goat cheese on top which gave it a bit of a "bite" and the sun dried tomatoes were also quite tasty.  My only complaint was that it was too freaking big! I felt bad leaving 1/4 of it but I just couldn't finish it. My partner had the eggs Benedict which he loved.  He also said the accompanying fruit was some of the freshest he's tasted in a while. However, Yolk did lose some points with both of us because of their less than stellar coffee.  So many breakfast places go wrong with their coffee.  Skip the Superior/Sysco supplied crap and serve Intelligentsia or Alterra and just charge a little more.  People will appreciate it. Aside from the bad coffee, we enjoyed our breakfast and will definitely be back!

I visited Yolk while on vacation over New Year's and fell in love with the place! We did hit a crowd which seems standard for this restaurant but it wasn't a long wait and it was managed well. I ordered the West Coast Crepes - fresh sliced avocado and mushrooms blended with scrambled eggs and melted cheddar & jack cheeses... then folded into two sweet crepes. It was the perfect mixture of sweet and savory with the slight sweetness from the crepes and the cheesy, saltiness of the filling. Everything I had heard about Yolk is true - it is a must on any trip to Chicago and I will absolutely be back!
Red Velvet Pancakes were a dream come true! Portions are huge! Had an omelet that was incredible as well!

Yum! Loved it here this past summer when my husband and I were in Chicago! We did not have to wait for a table, so that was nice. We loved their summer drink menu! My iced tea with mint was delightful and had free refills and my husband enjoyed his bottomless iced coffee (which was always refilled) as well. Our server was really friendly and helpful. I ordered the eggs benedict which came with a side of perfectly cooked red potatoes and some fruit. Awesome awesome place. Will definitely return.

Hip and clean with huge portions!  Went for breakfast early Sunday morning and was promptly seated at the bar. It wasn't crowded, but I could see it getting that way later in the morning.   I ordered the "Hey Ricky" omelet with fruit and pancakes.  Wow what a lot of food, plenty for two to share!  The omelet was prepared well, but the chorizo was a bit dry.  Along those lines of dry, I found the pancakes dry also.  They were probably prepared well in advance and kept warm somewhere before platting them.   Overall I found the atmosphere and staff cheery.  The food was good and could be considered a bargain if you were to split it with someone.  My total for the omelet($9.99) and a glass of juice($3.79) was $15 so in my opinion little pricey, but once again it is a lot of food. Next time I'm in Chicago and need a big fresh breakfast I know where to go....

I dont really get as to why this place gets such high ratings! I've been here a couple of times and each time the food was just mediocre at best.  The coffee has tasted burnt each time I've gotten it and they never have fresh cream available. Only the international delight pods. They also never have fresh butter available, only the pods again.  Also, the consistency seems to be non-exhistant. I've gotten the same dish twice in a row and both times they have looked and tasted different along with missing ingredients.  The service here is a hit or miss. It depends on the servers mood.  In all, this place is just OK.

It's always been confusing to me, exactly what the ratings on yelp are referring to.  Is it the food?  Is it the price?  Is it the wait time?  Is it the customer service? I'm not sure, but I'll write out the reasons why I docked stars for my reviews :) My girlfriend and I ordered from this place on day three of our stay at Chicago.  We wanted some breakfast, but didn't want to sit in anywhere so we placed our order over the phone.  The waitress was pleasant enough and assured us the food would be ready in 10 minutes.  Sure enough, by the time I reached the restaurant (changed + cleaned up + walked down = 13 minutes), our order was ready.  Walked out the door with my bank account 16 dollars cheaper (something like that). We ordered the Fruit and Nut pancakes (wanted to be a little on the healthy side ;p) and Fresh-Squeezed Orange Juice (16 oz). The pancakes were... not what we expected, to say the least.  Not that it was terrible!  But multi-grain batter pancakes aren't too yummy, which made us reconsider our "healthy" choice, but oh well!  Girlfriend didn't like it too much, and I'm less picky but still didn't enjoy it wholly, so half a star for that. The orange juice was GREAT.  Tasted really fresh, and we couldn't get enough.  Was a little surprised that 16 oz was so small, but that's not their fault.  No stars marked off there. Seems I can't give half stars, and 5 stars is a little generous, so 4 stars is all I can do :(

You can't screw up breakfast food and they didn't.  For a completely affordable price in the city, you can eat like a king with fresh fruit and great breakfast entree's.  It was awesome.  There was always a wait and the place was crowded, but sneak to the bar if you can and avoid the line.  Also, the wait goes quickly as its breakfast and the tables turn quickly.  Loved it.
Best breakfast I have had in a long time. Great staff.

I've been coming to Yolk since 2008 and return at least once every other month.  You might (or might not) be wondering, 'Sarah! Why haven't you written a review if you've been coming for almost five years?! That's a bit un-Yelp like,' why yes- my fellow Yelp enthusiast it is true. I should have written earlier. But I feel I can give you a well rounded review. I really do love this place. There have been a few times (especially on weekends when there is an hour or more wait) where I have thought 'ugh this place is overrated' yet I continued to come back- the food is that good.  Food is always top notch. This last visit was fantastic though. My family had a waiter named Jack. He was great. My father and brother were 45 minutes late; in the meantime Jack served me hot coffee and offered a paper to read. I really appreciated this small gesture. Atmosphere- great, bright, lively Service- Happy, not overly attentive, yet very perceptive Food- eggs benedict all the way

Went here for breakfast this morning with the family and I had a great "eggsperience"!!  I ordered the California omelette with eggwhites and without sour cream (it had mushrooms, tomatoes, green onions, avocado, and a dab of garlic and cheese on top) and that was delectable!!  A great omelette, but nothing TOO special. What I did love though were the MULTIGRAIN PANCAKES!  You don't have to pay extra to get the multigrain pancakes on the side instead of the buttermilk (you DO have to pay an extra $2. something to get the specialty pancakes) and they were super filling but light, fluffy, and delicious. Also, great medley of fresh fruit with my omelette!  A slice of honeydew, pineapple, some orange slices, and a bundle of VERY juicy, sweet, and perfectly plump red grapes.  It's always an extra treat when it's yummy to be healthy :) The only issue that my family had was that the corned beef hash was not "house-made", according to the waitress (my mom predicted that it came out of a can...). Lastly, to top off the experience we walked by a SWAT team eating breakfast in full uniform at a nearby table.  If it's good enough for them, it's good enough for me!

Cute place. Fast service on a Sunday. My boyfriend loved his biscuits n gravy. I ordered their eggs Benedict (voted best in Chicago claimed their menu). Not quite unfortunately. The plate was brought to me a complete mess. Potatoes and fruit were the sides but were completely mixed with the hollandaise sauce. Gross. The sauce tasted too much like Dijon mustard. Overpowering. Potential but probably won't go back for a while.

I've been here on a few different occasions. It's usually always busy but food is okay. Nothing too special but it's a nice brunch every once in a while. Service is normally good but it seems like they're just a little slow.

Great selection of breakfast options. Bright and open space. Did not feel rushed. I dined here in the morning on a Friday and pretty much every seat was filled. Waited less than 2 minutes for a table. I'm sure this is not the case over the weekend. I will definitely go back. Of course parking is an issue given the location. You are limited to the side streets and of course taking public transportion.

One of my favorite breakfast spots in the area - always have had to wait and it's always worth it!  Somehow, I consistently get my same eggs benedict here, but it's "just right" so why change up!? Service is excellent, even though they've always been extremely busy. PLUS, it's friendly service with a smile that makes you feel welcome, as does the large open space itself. It's a winner! This location is convenient getting off the Orange line at Roosevelt and then walking (yikes! even in 20 degrees...to the museum campus! The first time we did that, our bellies were so full and numb from the deliciousness that it didn't matter.)

My French toast was brutal, but when I asked the server about it she got the manager and he came over and remade the French toast...it was improved but still not good.  I gve credit for the service given the price point, manager was attentive, coffee was filled quickly.  The French toast is not worth even trying,it's dry on the inside and kind of tasted like they were using stale bread ( both times) butttt my friends egg Benedict she said was really good. So it's worth a visit but don't expect amazing.  If you are in the area I would probably just recommend wild berry which is north a few blocks But this is more casual, and maybe easier if you have kids as its bigger

So just a couple of random notes. This place was an OK brunch place. Has all the standard foods, and it was in my opinion more quantity than quality. We got the sweet crepe with avocado, and the smoked salmon eggs benedict. Crepe with avocado was a little mushy for my taste, and there was nothing spectacular about their benedict. Egg was a little over-poached, not enough oozage for me. Other notes: They have truvia at the table for your convenience - yay! The napkin cloth was really slippery and kept sliding off my lap - boo! The environment is really good, a lot of sun, nice interior - yay! The service was so-so because it was pretty busy I guess? - boo...

I met a couple of friends here for our monthly get-together/catch-up/girlfriends time.  The whole wait for an hour for breakfast is not hot. I understand it's  popular place but honestly I can cook breakfast at home. I'm a lunch/dinner type of girl. I had a skillet..a skillet of eggs, cheese and veggies. It was quick, well cooked and filling. Yolk does the job. I have no love, but I definitely have respect.

I came into Yolk with fairly high expectations but was sorely disappointed. I ordered the Callifornia Omlette due to the tasty description. Avocado, mushrooms, bacon, with a side of potatoes. Mmmm.  When I got the dish, the omlette was of a green tone from the avocados being blended into the egg. Quite odd and tasteless. The potatoes were too mushy and very unevenly salted. I was not Impressed at all.

Love Yolk! I genuinely, legitimately, do not think it's possible that they have a single item on the menu that isn't delectable! Sometimes breakfast joints can be a pain in the booty for us vegetarian folk, but not Yolk. There are countless veggie dishes on the menu and they'll customize just about whatever you want. I love the California omelette and the caprese benny is to die for! Their Hollandaise sauce is just about perfection. Also, don't be looking for those icky shredded hash browns in this joint, no siree. You'll get some of the yummiest fried red potatoes (home fries) ever to touch your lips - ask for them extra crispy, you'll thank me later. Every meal on the menu is huge and comes with a selection of sides, so be prepared to stuff your face! Bottomless (good) coffee that's pretty cheap, I think $2. All of the dishes are sooooo reasonably priced especially considering the portion size and quality. I don't know that I've actually ever finished an entire meal here! The only negative can be service and the fact that it gets so incredibly busy on the weekends it can be a little overwhelming, especially if you're getting over a rough night. Also, they close at 3 pm, which is a little early for Sunday brunch seeing as I have a tough time dragging my bum out of bed anytime before the pm hours. But, it's worth it! All in all, this is definitely my go-to breaky/brunch joint and I don't see that changing anytime soon! Eat up!

My husband and I recently ate here while in town for Thanksgiving. All I can say is, "HEY RICKY!" soooo goood! I love anything with chorizo, but this was extra amazing! It was spicy with jalapeno's and had the added touch of avacado's mashed right up in there, mmmm mmmm. Had that with a side of delicious home potatoes and strawberry orange juice. Portions were huge, split this with my husband as our savory dish and shared some pumpkin spiced french toast thing that was a special for our sweet dish.  Will most definitely be back!

Starving? Good. Come here, and I guarantee you, you will leave full. VEGGIE SKILLET: Just about the cutest thing ever -- it's actually served in a silver skillet! The skillet includes zuchinis, asparagus, spinach, mushrooms, tomatoes, and potatoes. This is ALL covered in a generous heaping of eggs and cheese. Yum! Everything was super fresh. The cheese/egg combo over all those veggies were amazing. The best part? It wasn't heavy, and it wasn't oily at all! Definitely one healthy meal. CAJUN "SHROOM SCRAMBLER": Scrambled eggs with red pepper, onions, zucchinis, and topped with a GIANT portabella mushroom. And I mean GIANT. It's one huge shroom on steroid. The mushroom was the most memorable because it was so moist and savory.  BOTH entrees came with a side of either home fries, fruit & toast, english muffin, or 2 pancakes (with MAPLE syrup, it's the real deal!) This could easily be a meal for 3 people...and all for under $20!!! What a steal! TIP: Come during OFF PEAK hours, because the long can be horrendous. TIP #2: Remember to grab some CHOCOLATE COVERED MINTS at the end! So delicious! Wish I grabbed two ):

My kids and I LOVE Yolk!  We recently moved out of the city and during the 4 months preceding our move, we vowed to eat at yolk at least once a week.  I love either veg omelets, my son is particular to the pancakes and my daughter is addicted to the French Toast. Hands down our favorite breakfast place in the city. Yummy with consistent food and predictable staff. Highly recommended!
If you like breakfast, you will love this place. Hot food, served pretty quick by a freindly staff.  Large portions and reasonable prices.
Great breakfast food with generous portions in a bustling atmosphere for a good price.

On a recent trip to Chicago, we were in search of an open-early breakfast locale.  This was a very solid choice, and I credit the great yelp reviews for leading us here! Pros: Even though it's busy, the wait was not that long at all The food came so fast that it felt almost comical Strawberry Orange juice was awwweeeesome Eggs come with a choice of home fries or...pancakes?  Cons: HUGE portions.  A scramble has a side of 2 pancakes. totally crazy. I didn't love my salmon omelette.  It came without the capers and, imo, not enough cream cheese

Great breakfast/brunch place!  Consistently delicious, and there are so many items on the menu that you basically never run out of new ones to try.  I highly recommend getting the fresh-squeezed orange juice!  Sometimes there's a bit of a wait, but if you show up early-ish or call ahead for pick-up, it's a non-issue.  I would suggest sticking to the egg dishes, as they tend to be more enjoyable than the pancakes/waffles/french toast/etc. Not too expensive either, less than $15/person.

On my second trip to Chicago I had breakfast there everyday!!!!  I was traveling by myself so I was lucky and never had to wait, even on Saturday or Sunday.  But if you are going any of those days, be ready to wait for a long time.  You won't be disappointed, their food is delicious!  During my visits I had banana nut bread french toast, waffles, Nutella and banana crepes and last day I had their breakfast quesadilla.  Everything was really good. Their food is pricey but their portions compare to the price.  I love their fresh orange and strawberry juice! Service is as good or better than their food, even on Saturday and Sunday when the place was packed.   I will definitely visit Yolk again next time I'm in town!!!!!
Great breakfast place. It's not that far from downtown and just in front of museum campus. The food is great as this is one of the most famous restaurant for breakfast in Chicago.

Just had brunch here and I think A-OK sums it up pretty good.  My friend got the challah french toast and I had the fall seasonal special cheeseburger benedict. Nothing particularly special about either item, but both were solidly good.  I thought the benedict was a bit plain.  The egg was perfectly poached, but flavor wise the dish was light on seasonings.  I kept comparing it to the duck-confit benedict I had at Over Easy, which might not be fair but it fell very short. My friend thought the french toast was good, but it's french toast so it'd take effort to screw up. Since I live in the South Loop, I'd probably come back when other friends visit just for the location, but there are many more solid brunch options to be found in this fair city. One weird thing-- because they have you take your check up to the front to pay we almost didn't.  Let me explain.   I went to the bathroom leaving my friend sitting at the counter with the check.  He decided to also go to the bathroom and leave the check sitting on the counter.  Not quite sure what he was thinking.  Anyway, neither of us left jackets in the area so I think they assumed we had left. When I got back other people had already taken the seats we vacated so I assumed my friend had gone up to pay the bill.  After wandering around in confusion for a bit we went up to the register and asked if they had our bill.  Their response was, "oh we weren't sure if you guys had left." Um, does that happen often?  Seems like a poor setup.  Or maybe they figure that their establishment is nice enough that they won't attract dine & ditch riff-raff?  Maybe they will after this review.  Oops.

Yolk is really good but really busy!  This is one of their three locations in the larger downtown area, and I recommend it for breakfast.  But if you're coming on a Saturday or Sunday, expect to wait a long time to be seated. I'm a big fan of their omelets, but the menu is so deep that no matter what your breakfast craving is they'll satisfy it.  I really like that all meals come with a choice of toast, english muffin, or pancake.  Oftentimes at breakfast places I want to get a pancake as a side with a savory meal, but can't. So I'd give Yolk all the stars in the world for a Monday-Friday breakfast.  Just docked the one star for the wait time.  I recommend it and think you'll enjoy it.
Great atmosphere. Food is good not great. Had to add quite a bit of seasoning to make it palatable.

Just like my last visit to Yolk - I left smiling, full and delighted from my amazingly delicious breakfast.  I decided to head to a different Yolk location this trip- this one is right across the street from the beautiful Millennium Park on South Michigan Ave. I was greeted by a really nice hostess who seated me promptly. As soon as I opened the menu I spotted their famous strawberry orange juice which was sweet and refreshing. So glad I had this over my typical coffee as I walked close to a mile to get there.  (YES!!! It's that imperative I visit Yolk on every trip to the Chi!) I ordered my favorite scrambled eggs with cheese, roasted potatoes and a side of red velvet french toast = honestly it's heaven on a breakfast plate. The amount they give you is amazing and although they're a tad bit pricier than your typical breakfast spot - it's definitely worth every penny.  I had such a nice meal, paid my bill at the front and almost walked out the door before an employee ran up to me with my coat in his arms that I had forgotten at my seat. It was an absolutely gorgeous morning in the city so it slipped my mind completely - no part of me would have remembered it so I was extremely thankful he went out of his way to return it to me.  I was heading straight to the airport after my breakfast so it would have been a wrap if not. So on top of the amazing food- their service is top notch as well.  Thanks for a memorable breakfast yet again Yolk - you never disappoint.   Signed with love, Marina R
Great place for breakfast. Fresh orange juice was great many healthy vegan options on the menu.

The place came recommended, but I have to report a shocking disappointment. I really hesitate to complain about much, but my breakfast started poorly with a coffee cup so badly chipped there wasn't an inch of intact rim.  So, as politely as I could muster, I requested a new one.  The waitress, bless her, was perhaps too honest and said that they probably didn't have anything better but she'd go and look for me. My grapes! Oh, the memory haunts me, and - if you care to see - I do have a photo.  My grapes - each and every one of them - left a dirty pool of smudged dirt on the plate where they were sitting.  Not so much washed, but wetted and left to drizzle their accumulated dirt on my plate. My maple syrup (that should probably be put in quotes - I'm sure it was corn syrup) had a skin that I decided to look past in order to at least have SOMETHING to moisten the pancakes. All that said, the food was passable, but I really see no reason to suffer through the dubious cleanliness on any future visit to this fine town. High points: - um Low points: - see above

My first visit to this South Loop restaurant on a bustling Saturday morning was a delicious, and overall positive, experience.  Despite the large crowd of already waiting visitors, my friend and I were seated within 25 minutes.  Our berry crunch oatmeal, veggie skillet, and Tour de France (plate featuring 3 different types of french toast) arrived in  a reasonable amount of time and our server was attentive during their morning rush. The highlight of the meal was absolutely the Tour de France which featured lemon-poppyseed, orange, and banana french toast topped with fresh blueberries, strawberries, and bananas, respectively.  This plate was accompanied by peanut butter and orange marmalade toppings and made for a delicious compliment to the egg skillet. Overall, the portions were generously sized and the quality of the food was certainly above average.  One complaint that I had regarding my experience, however, was that the pancakes which were supposed to accompany my egg skillet simply never arrived.  We ended up not bringing it up (as we had more than enough food to share), but it was still a blemish on an otherwise impeccable breakfast experience. Recommended Dish:  Tour de France

Yolk was on my list for my next visit to Chicago and my opportunity to eat there finally came after a trip to the Shedd Aquarium. Although we got to the restaurant only half an hour shy of closing time, they let us in, seated us, and didn't rush us one bit. Already a great impression! I ordered the Zamboni Crêpes with fresh fruit and pancakes. I was not expecting so much food! Two big crêpes with tons of stuffing (eggs, spinach, ham...), medium-sized flapjacks, and lots of fruit. I took home a whole crepe and half of the pancakes. My cousin and I also split some Nutella crêpes with bananas. So absolutely delicious. My cousin's kid had a good time coloring - the waiter even brought some extra crayons so he had more colors - and seemed to enjoy his pancakes. My auntie and uncle could not believe how much food was served, nor how inexpensive the meal was! It was tough to choose from such an extensive menu with such reasonable prices. I was totally impressed. We even were able to charge our devices; I told the hostess that I was the only person with a phone - my relatives were visiting from Canada and didn't want to deal with roaming charges - so they let my plug my phone in for a while near the register and I later plugged it in by my seat. The servers even knew which tables had outlets nearby. Whenever I come back, there will be tons of options. There will be plenty of options for many more visits to come! That might just be their trick... and based on how good all the food was on my first visit, I'm certain it will be great the next time. I hear it gets busy, but I can deal with a wait. I think I have a new tradition... Yolk for brunch in the middle of a museum day. Perfect!

Bland menu, rude host and lady taking down names, and bland food do not a positive review make. You know something is wrong when the garnish is better than the food. The eggs were far from fresh, and the lady who took down names was just ridiculously rude. Then we have the host himself, who is some guido-looking douchebag who was visibly treating people horribly. The eggs benedict were just poorly, poorly made. They weren't even consistently cooked. I can advise people to not come here. There is nothing special, other than a wait in line for really really bland and uncreative food. How can a place not even offer soymilk or skim milk? Only 2%? Blech.  Not coming here again. Not worth the time. Then again, you get what you pay for considering this place is cheap.

Long wait (no chairs or benches to sit on while you wait), bad service, decent food. This place is obviously very crowded on a Sunday morning so expect to wait. We waited 45 minutes. Our server should be in any other industry but service. I asked for coffee and when she brought it she just set it down on the opposite side of table where there was an empty seat. Very strange. She brought no cream so when she passed by again I asked for some. I waited 10 minutes. Our food appeared but still no cream. I asked again. She brought it out 5 minutes later with the toast my friend was waiting patiently for so she could start eating her now-cold eggs. No water refills. She checked in with us when we were done eating and ready for the check. Of course, by that time you are just happy you are no longer starving and anxious to depart this very noisy, dish-clattering "we're the it place to eat breakfast so we really don't care if you're happy" restaurant. Then, you get to wait in line to pay a bill with the single register. Clearly this is a family-owned business with old-school tendencies which I can appreciate but it wouldn't kill them to trust another employee to operate a second register during their busy times. Not too mention their register area is right in the middle of all the commotion and all of the people standing there waiting to pay, picking up carry-out, and ordering coffee to go are really in the way of customers and servers alike. The highlight is their creative menu and their generous portions. I had the Zamboni crepes which were yummy. They came with a side of fresh fruit and pancakes which I realize is a whole other meal. Plus, the fruit was fresh cut and assorted-grapes, pineapple, melon, oranges-which was really nice. I was so full from the crepes I didn't want to even eat the pancakes but I did try one bite and they were delish! Obviously a lot of passion and planning went into the menu so if they can get their service up to par this place would rock....or at least rock more than it already does if the people waiting outside are any indication.

we were visiting Chicago for the first time. so we asked are bell men where to eat breakfast. one of them told us to try yolk and the other one told us to try 11 city diner. so we decided to try 11 city diner first. the food was great but kinda pricy. the next day we got up and went to yolk. it was soooooo good. the strawberry oj and the red velvet french toast was to die for.  i often have fantasies of driving to chi just to get my yolk fix.

Had breakfast here. The food is fast and fresh. The whole place feels light and sunny and the staff smile. Eggs cooked just the way you order them and lots of healthy alternatives to fried on fried. Good value for money and they keep filling your coffee cup

Went here for brunch with a couple of friends. Best decision ever. They have HUGE portions and they are delicious. I had their chocolate and strawberry cakes (pancakes) plus the red velvet french toast. OMG. I'm not a fan of pancakes but boy those were good! And their hot chocolate is okay, not bad, but definitely have had better. My friends had the garden burger and she said it was the best vegetarian burger she's ever had (it looked really good), one skillet and the nutella crepe. We were all in our little piece of heaven. The service was okay, we came in a not so busy time but our server seemed far off somewhere. It was still good though. This place however does seem to get super full, so you probably want to get in early on the weekends, or make a reservation for brunch. You don't want to miss out. Also, you pay at the front, which can speed up the check out process, especially if you are splitting the bill...

I went to lunch with my grandma.  We are both gluten free.  I was surprised that the restaurant seemed progressive but yet didn't have indications of gf options.  We both opted for a salad.  I had the Greek salad with balsamic dressing.  it was really good but I think it was contaminated.
I am a regular here. I like their crepes, skillets, omelets, salads, egg benedict ... well, just about everything on their menu is good. Expect to wait to be seated on Sunday mornings.

In the midst of a weekend of eating deep dish pizzas and hot dogs everywhere, Yolk was a wonderfully healthful alternative for brunch/lunch-they seem serve the whole menu all day.  Funky decor and not a long wait for your food once you are seated- which on weekends can take a bit.  The service is efficient and friendly and you will leave perfectly full.  Eggs done anyway you can imagine with what seems like infinite amount of quality veggies, meats and cheeses.  I got the iron man egg white omelet due to all my other chicago dining guilt and it was really satisfying.  It's not all uber healthy though, the nutella crepes looked sinful, and my fellow diners clearly enjoyed and everything was priced fairly.  And my other friends turkey burger on a pretzel bun was delish.  I  def recommend.

Now I see why they are just a breakfast joint, because they know how to do it real well.  Yolk on Michigan Av. is huge and yet there is always a wait on the weekends.  The interior is clean & unique although it can get pretty loud.  They have many of the classics & some lighter fare as well.  I like their Eggs Benedict better than most in the city.  Having been here several times I can also say that 90% of the servers are friendly & good.   There is not much for parking around there other than parking garage to the North or some Meters to the West on State.
A wide selection of unique breakfast options. I had the carrot cake french toast which was unbelievable. Food is a bit pricey but worth the experience.

Just constantly good. The wait on a weekend day can be a pain but I don't think there's any brunch place where you wouldn't have to wait. All the dishes and sweets are good and the service is mostly very nice and quick. Like it and keep going.

I came here during my first visit to Chicago during Taste of Chicago. The decor was super cute. My friend and I came kind of knowing what we want. The menu is jam packed with interesting sounding deliciousness. Indecisive and greed had us deciding on ordering a personal entree each and sharing one. No regrets here! I ordered the Tuscan Frittata. SO yummy. It was my first time trying a frittata and I def will order more. It was well seasoned, had chicken, potatoes, sundried tomatoes and fresh basil. On the menu it says goat cheese. I thought the cheese would be IN the frittata, not smeared on top. Not good for presentation and I had a ehhh face BUT the taste DEF made up for it.  My friend order the Chocolate Strawberry Pancakes. Looked amazing. Tasted just as amazing. I'm not big on sweet stuff and it was drizzled in chocolate syrup, but it was good. My friend loved it. Now the best part of the meal. We shared the (stuffed) Red Velvet French Toast. OMG. That's all I'll say. So good. LOVED IT. All in all, the food was great. Service was great. Price was great. I wish there was one in NYC. Until then I look forward to my next trip to the Chi!

Yolk is awesome. This place is very busy, yet organized and clean. Food are very well made. They are cooked just to the right point.  I had delicious omelet and fresh fruits for breakfast. Surely will come again if I am in the area!

Went for breakfast with teen daughters...ordered red velvet french toast, peach struessel crepes, santa fe frittatta with cilantro, jalapenos, and avocado, and of course eggs benedict.   All food was amazing, fresh, delicious and served in large portions with a smile...where else can you get a large glass of fresh squeezed orange juice these days.  About $85 with tip for 2 adults, 2 teenagers and a tween.  Worth every penny, best breakfast in recent memory, great atmosphere and great location.

While in Chicago Last weekend , my entourage & I went to 2 locations of  YOLK for brerakfast and both times it was excellent , I had The french toast combo, The french toast was good , but The Bacon & Sausages were outstanding. Price was very Reasonable. I will return next time in Chi Town

Meh. I came here this past Saturday for brunch. There was a 40 minute wait, which is to be expected, however it ended up not being worth the wait.  Our server was miserable, and it took 10 minutes after being seated before she appeared for the first time. When she took our order she didn't listen to me at all. I ordered the chocolate chip strawberry pancakes with no chocolate sauce on top. She said "so you just want strawberry pancakes". Umm no, if you are familiar with your own menu, you would know there are chocolate chips in the actual batter. I had to show her the menu description. I also ordered a side of pork sausage and as she wrote it down said "side of turkey sausage". They don't even sound alike, please listen.  Once you get the bill, you have to stand in line to pay at the counter. Maybe this helps them turn the tables over faster but standing in a line that starts in the middle of the restaurant where you are blocking those dining at the counter, dodging out of the way of servers delivering trays of food, and waiting 20 minutes to pay really detracts from my overall dining experience.  The vibe and atmosphere felt very much like a chain restaurant. If I didn't know any better I'd have sworn I was at Denny's.  The food actually was pretty decent and inexpensive. I thought my pancakes, which came out correctly much to my surprise, were good although did not come with enough syrup. Part of my enjoyment could have been the fact that it was 1:30 before I ate for the first time that day.  With so many amazing brunch spots in the city, do yourself a favor and skip this place unless you like enduring long waits and poor service for mediocre, chain restaurant quality.
Fast and friendly..great service. Food was hot, delicious, and well presented. The omelettes and fried potatoes are amazing! Good prices! Highly recommend.

Ordered catering from Yolk for a client meeting and hot damn was it good. If you want to stand out from the traditional bagels, yogurt THIS is the place to order from Sante Fe frittata - holy delicious. Love the avocado and jalapeno. So good for a catered pan of frittata Nutella crepes - Um....if you serve nutella crepes to anyone they will fall instantly in love with you Mixed Fruit - you can tell it was fresh. Non of that pre-cut been sitting for a while crap Mixed pastries - yummy mix of bagels/muffins cut in halfs/quarters which made it super easy to share.  I will definitely be ordering catering here from now on! It's a little far for me to visit the actual storefront, but I have been to the actual location a few years back and need to visit again!
The pot roast eggs benedict is the best thing I've ever had. omg. Red velvet french toast is super rich so share it with someone. Great atmosphere, good service, usually a wait

I went on a Monday morning with my family. Luckily there was a short wait. The place is a lot bigger than I had expected (we were so used to going to hole-in-the-walls). The server was okay but at least he was attentive.  The portions are huge! That's coming from a family that can eat. Luckily almost all of us split dishes. The strawberry orange juice is delicious! Order it! The coffee is on the stronger side, and they were good about keeping it filled.  1) Huevos Rancheros (over-easy eggs with chorizo, salsa, and cheese over corn tortillas. Served with sour cream, red diced potatoes or fresh fruit) 2) Santa Fe Frittata (bacon, avocado, three cheeses scrambled with jalapenos, green onions, and grilled red diced potatoes) 3) Sliced avocado and mushrooms blended with scrambled eggs and melted cheddar & jack cheeses, then folded in to two sweet crepes. - Loved it! Sweet yet savory. Everyone enjoyed their food. The food was good, classical breakfast.
Pecan waffles, and Santa Fe frittata...so wonderful!  A must visit when in town.

Love breakfast? Yolk's your place. Don't love breakfast? Yolk is still your place. Hate eggs? You can STILL find something on the menu. Yolk is my go-to place when someone suggests brunch. The food is excellent, the portions are huge, and the service is top-notch. Now, it is a busy place, so if you're looking something quiet, I wouldn't come here. But otherwise, this place is great for a date or groups of people. I am an egg-lover, so I always look for eggs that I can't make at home, or would be too time-consuming. Yolk has a huge variety of egg options, which always overwhelms me. Their french toast is also to die for. I usually don't order sweet things like that for breakfast, but I will at Yolk because they're unique and always delicious. (Try the Red Velvet French Toast sometime--holy CRAP! WOW.) Anyway, if you're looking for a good brunch place, come to Yolk. If you're looking for a good brunch place for either a date or group, come to Yolk. If you're looking for something intimate, maybe not, though I've never had a problem talking to my date.

Great breakfast place in downtown Chicago. I lived in Museum Park area for 7 years. Always too much food in the serving size, so order accordingly. Can be a bit pricey even for Chicago. Yet, the best breakfast/brunch place in the neighborhood.

We've been looking for different breakfast places for a while and then decided to try this place out thanks to all of our fellow Yelpers. Since it got pretty good reviews, we decided to go for brunch on a Sunday. We found parking about a block away on the street and walked over, gave our name, and waited outside with everyone else. It was packed. We didn't have to wait too long and got a good seat.  The menu is pretty great with a lot of different things on the menu. After a while trying to decide, the wife and I finally decided to order our breakfast. Ambiance is very lively with a clean feel. The staff is friendly and quite quick with the service which is something I need when I go out to eat and pay for my food. I had an omelet with toast and the wife had a crepe omelet with pancakes on the side. The food was good and tasty. The portions were also generous. I would definitely recommend this place to anyone looking for a good brunch/breakfast spot. This place has it all.

If you're looking for a place to have a hearty breakfast, look no further--Yolk is  your place.   When you first look at the menu, it may be a bit overwhelming, as they have so many delicious items to choose.  However, I'm more of an omelet person, so I have tried almost all of their omelet dishes and they are quite tasty.  My boyfriend usually gets their skillet dish; which to my amazement, he manages to eat it all.  FYI - The portions here are pretty generous.  If you do plan to visit this place, expect to wait between 20- 25 minutes on weekends.  I usually wait outside and sit along the flower beds.  They have an outdoor intercom so you can hear when they call your name.  Some opted to wait inside; however, it's just a big open space for people to stand.  As one reviewer previously noted, wish they utilized the open space---they can easily put 4-5 additional tables there, or provide seats if they plan to use it as a waiting area.   The ambiance is modern, vibrant, and airy.  The service is prompt.  The location is excellent---just minutes away from the Millennium Park.   Enjoy!

I caught up with the law school girls on a Saturday at Yolk for a quick breakfast. I had tried coming here on one other occasion but the wait was too long. Fortunately we got there early enough that we only had to wait a few minutes. But after having actually eaten the food, I can definitely say that it's not a breakfast that I would go out of my way for or wait more than a few minutes. The space is nice, not too loud. My friend and her little one appreciated the "stroller parking" off to the side. The service was fine for a breakfast place, except we had no spoons for our coffee (despite a couple of requests), which should be a no-brainer. As far as food, I ordered the nutella crepes and next time would order something else. I did not think that anything with nutella (and gobs of it) should at the same time be doused in chocolate syrup. Also it was just a very heavy dish. My girlfriends seemed to like their breakfasts but weren't blown away.

OVERRATED... not too different from ihop or denny's. although the price is worth the portion, the taste was confusing. the crepes were too sweet. the potatoes/hash were not tasty enough. nothing special. skip if you could.

My favorite breakfast place in the city! And yes... we've tried them all!! They have a large menu and huge portions. Food is always consistently delicious. (Personally recommend their sweet crepes!) Wish they had seating in the enormous waiting area... or even more tables so less people would have to stand and wait! It's always packed during the prime breakfast hours, but most places are anyway. They also need sugar dispensers instead of the packaged sugar, as we always have to ask for more.  Excellent food, excellent service! I definitely recommend it to anyone looking for a good hearty breakfast.

I've wanted to try Yolk for awhile, and with my parents in town, finally got a chance to check it out.  After a 25 minute wait (pretty standard for Sunday), we sat down at a table in the back.  The restaurant was definitely busy, but the tables seemed to be turning over relatively quickly, so the wait didn't bother us. The menu had a huge array of breakfast items, and it was interesting to see that salmon is a focus in quite a few dishes. Here's what we had: Huevos rancheros - SO good; fresh jalapenos and perfectly cooked eggs Salmon scramble - rich and flavorful, but could do without the cream cheese French toast - AMAZING Ham omelet - delicious and served with a side of fruit Fresh squeezed juice The portion sizes were quite large (only my dad finished), and the prices were super reasonable.  Would definitely recommend Yolk as one of my new favorite breakfast spots in the city.

This place was great! I got the French Toast Combo which came with 2 eggs, 2 pieces of sausage, and 2 pieces of bacon. The bacon was cold and not very flavorful, but everything else was great! My boyfriend got the Carnitas sandwich which was on a pretzel bun with goat cheese and a fried egg.  We got the potato pancakes to share among the table and those were DELISH. Came with classic applesauce and sour cream. Portion sizes were HUGE as everyone has been saying, so come hungry ;)

I've lived in South Loop now for 5 years, and this place is no good. Go to the Bongo Room if you want breakfast. Yolk has large portion sizes, and a nice atmosphere.. but the food is bland and flavorless. I can't recommend a single plate... perhaps get a wrap if you're forced to come here- and prepare to wait for a long time.    If you're going to wait to get in somewhere, wait for the BongoRoom on Wabash. The Yolk is good to the typical American taste (flavorless), the ingredients are the cheapest you can get ahold of- this place is the high fructose corn syrup of the breakfast world. If you've never left the US and never lived in France, Spain, Mexico or Italy (visiting won't qualify for building a real palate), you enjoy large portion sizes with no flavor- eat up at the Yolk.

I love this place!  But beware... certain times of summer it can get PACKED with tourists! The portions are ridiculously  HUGE.  Any time I go for breakfast, I have enough leftovers for lunch as well.  I have become quite a fan of the "bacon quesadilla", which I have to put in quotes because it's really more of a breakfast wrap.  It's eggs, bacon, cheese, and I pay extra for black beans in a multigrain wrap.  YUM.  And again, massive portions make for a nice lunch as well.  The strawberry-orange juice is a nice complement. The coffee isn't great... I tend to like Metropolis but it must be how they make it here.  It's been weak on occasion.  They also don't do espresso drinks, which is a bummer for me.  They have one of those latte/cappuccino machines like they have at 7-11 but that is just not acceptable for me.  The one thing I DO like when it comes to the coffee?  The little bowls on each table filled with a variety of individual cups of flavored creamer!  White chocolate mocha and caramel macchiato?  That helps the days when the coffee is sub-par.

Yolk was totally egg-cellent. Don't worry, the rest of the review will more than make up for that joke, so keep reading. We came on a busy Sunday lunch, but were seated after 5 min.  I ordered the Veggie Skillet, which consisted of perfectly cooked asparagus, zucchini, peppers, etc., AS WELL AS 3 fluffy pancakes. All for $10 - say what?! The dutiful (and gorgeous) waitress filled our coffee and water far more frequently than I expected, and with a smile to boot.  Cool decor, hip, happening - a nice South Loop joint. Go to Yolk. Go often.

I don't know why this place doesn't have higher ratings.   I came in at a busy time but was greeted nicely and seated promptly by a nice gentleman.  I ordered a South of the Border Benny's (I think that's what it's called) and it rocked my world.  The chorizo and Hollandaise on it was perfect and it came out VERY fast.  Their service is just great.  I also ordered a side of bacon, not realizing that their portions are very big.  It was so good that I managed to eat everything still.  The restaurant style is very modern and the bathroom is very clean.  Please come to California!

I've never written a Yolk review? Geez... I guess I don't write reviews often for my regular spots. I'm a brunch person all the way and Yolk stays in my rotation. The wait is always super long. 30 minutes would be fabulous but expect 1 hour. The food is good and I always leave stuffed... just the way I like it after brunch! Hey... I walk home afterwards so that makes me feel better. =)
Not bad. I had whole grain pancakes, which were tasty, but heavy for a pancake. That may be do to my flour choice though.

We waited for about 20 minutes. It started out with a reservation for 4, but once we were seated we realized 2 more would be joining us. We figured we could all just squeeze in the booth, but the hostess was very accommodating and quickly found us a larger table. Aside from the spastic waiter we had everything was wonderful. We all ordered something different. There was not one item that was disappointing! I had a stuffed omelet, someone had crepes, another pancakes...I can just keep going! I highly recommending this place!

4.5 stars. Really, Yelp?  Only 3.5 stars for Yolk?  This place brings it hard.  Just take a look at the ARMY of short order cooks pumping out perfectly cooked breakfast food that not only tastes great, but looks great too.  Plus, with the level of quality this place delivers consistently it certainly doesn't break the bank.  I was thrilled to live a block away. Everything I've ever gotten here, and this is a lot of stuff off their extensive menu has delivered.  I have brought many friends and family here, and it has always gone over well.   Bananas Foster crepes?  Red velvet cake french toast?  Huge portions, not so good the next day, but delicious. Breakfast sandwich?  Sure throw some pesto on there while your at it... practically perfection. Every egg dish I've ever had there... perfectly prepared. Fresh squeezed orange juice and ripe, delicious fruit scattered over everything. I'm sorry people.... get with the program on this one.  I respectfully disagree. Oh, go at the right time.  You WILL be waiting on Saturday and Sunday for brunch.  Don't hold it against them for being great.

Yolk was another restaurant that I had wanted to try for a long time. Unfortunately, it was a major letdown during a recent Sunday brunch. It receives one star primarily because of health safety concerns. As a pescatarian, I don't eat bacon. Why did pieces of bacon (undercooked fat and cooked portions) appear in my plain BELGIAN WAFFLE (substituted in the TWO EGG $5.99 combo for about $3 extra)? This problem did not happen just once. It happened a second time when I requested a redo of my entire order. The other problem with the initial order was that the RED DICED POTATOES were burnt. They were just less burnt on the second attempt. I looked at the plate of a lone diner seated next to us, and her potatoes looked burnt as well. If a restaurant can't make the time to clean waffle irons properly, then they should dedicate irons solely to specific types of waffles to help prevent cross contamination. The waiter was understanding, yet it was a challenge to flag him down in the huge and very loud dining room. He offered to supply me with a couple of pancakes. I should have refused. A serious case of the "lead in stomach" effect happened soon after. Those were the heaviest pancakes that I had eaten in a long time. I felt a bit queasy in the bathroom, along with a burgeoning headache, after eating half. Also, my friend felt queasy after eating her pancakes, then noticed that one of her bacon pieces looked severely overcooked. It looked like a black, corroded strip of meat. It was replaced, but by then we were more than ready to give up on the experience. We were comped the waffle on the bill and the eggs were cooked correctly, but we have no intention of ever returning. I like to eat more than eggs for brunch.

Wow...the food here looks pretty on the plate, tastes great too.   The portions are so big that two can easily share, and the prices are very reasonable.  I enjoyed savory crepes that are served with potatoes or fruit as well as pancakes, english muffin, or toast.  Big breakfast that is for sure....you get not 1 but 2 large crepes.  I brought one home for tomorrow.  I also enjoyed their delicious fresh squeezed orange/strawberry juice.  When we arrived they said it would be an hour for a table but we got seated in about 30 minutes or so as it is a big place with people coming and going all of the time.  Would love to come back.

Met friends from out of town for brunch here this morning.  Our party was large - 9 to be precise.  They don't take reservations on Saturday mornings, so we waited.  And waited.  And waited some more.  It took about 45 minutes, but were seated at around 10:30AM. The place is cute.  It's bright and friendly.  Once we were seated, the service was good.   I ordered corned beef hash and eggs.  It came with fresh fruit and toast.  Everything was good and the portions were large.  In fact, the bread was probably about half a loaf of rye bread. With nine people, there was a lot of variety at the table - Belgian waffles, Omelets, French Toast (with different fruit flavored breads) and even a cheeseburger.  Everyone seemed happy about the food. I didn't have coffee (I'm a Starbucks addict), but was told the coffee was good and strong. If you like your coffee sweet, they only have Truvia or sugar. The price was fairly reasonable.  It's a long haul from our house to get there.  (10 minutes to the train station, an hour on the train, then a cab ride to the restaurant.)  So, it's unlikely we'll return.  But, if we lived in the city, I would try Yolk again.

I'll rave about this place. I went on a Thursday, late morning, sat at the counter next to another out of towner like myself. Service was great, though the place was hoppin busy. I had a made to order skillet of vegetables (zucchini, mushrooms, spinach, asparagus & fresh tomato) minus the red potatoes with a bit of shredded cheddar (not a dousing of it, but a taste) & two over easy eggs atop it. This is their Vegetarian Skillet, made to order. It was perfect! The eggs were just perfection & the veggies were fresh, top quality and cooked just right.  Coffee was good and it kept coming. They had regular and flavored creamers. For my side I had a pancake - this was cooked fluffy and golden crisp on its edges, again- just right. I'll see you again next summer, and that's no yolk, Yolk!

Oh Yolk, how I love thee name. Scrambled, sunny side, over easy, you name and I'll eat it especially that delicious yellow goodness of a Yolk. Came here after a race downtown on a Sunday morning and boy were thou busy! Possibly overly busy due to the a lot of race participants looking for some grub and oj to keep them from dropping over.  The PA system worked well, people outside heard them, but they did favor people they "knew" over others that have been waiting for 20 minutes or more. But who doesn't play favorites when their friends walk in? I opted for the Southwest Benny ( yelp.com/user_local_phot… ) which was pretty decent, love the chorizo. My right arm man, the bf went with the French Toast Combo ( yelp.com/user_local_phot… ) which he enjoyed, but he's had better FT before. I wish I had the same love for thou as I do for the Yolk itself, unfortunately, since I'm a suburbanite I wouldn't travel the great distance.
This place is absolutely amazing. Food, service, and atmosphere- all great! Such a creative menu and great prices too. one plate of food could probably feed two people though

I really enjoy Yolk when my husband and I go often Saturday mornings. It does get really crowded after 8:30 am but we manage to get there before then. I had the Eggs Benedict and the Eggs Caprese (not in the same day :-) and they were DELICIOUS!! Just don't forget to request eggs well done as I have, because these two dishes call for poached eggs that are a bit runny, although sometimes I like them that way, it's better to have them well done. The coffee isn't bad either. For the  money, nice atmosphere and good food, it's worth it!! Be warned, this place is crazy crowded after 8:30am on Saturday mornings (and I am assuming Sundays too) expect a wait and you won't be too disappointed finally getting your food.

With a place named after part of an egg, it better be "egg-cellent."  As tradition with new brunch places, the eggs benedict is always my rule of thumb.  Make a good one and I shall come back; fail to do so and you will experience my wrath.  It turns out "Yolk" boasts the "best Eggs benedict in town."  Bold statement indeed.  Perhaps it was THAT statement that heightened my expectation. The eggs benedict was your typical one so I won't go in detail (if you don't know what it is, shame on you!).  It was good but was it the best? No.  My only gripe?  It was way too salty (the top of my lip started to tingle...did they put MSG?!).  Though, kudos to their fresh squeezed strawberry orange juice.

Too busy and too loud. Very long wait for breakfast food that's good but nothing special to note. I've had omelets and waffles here. It seems usual. Can't really mess up breakfast food, but I've had better elsewhere. They have large portions which is great except I can't really finish it and I'm not going to pack breakfast food. Not sure what the hype is all about. I think bongo room, Meli cafe, and over easy cafe are much better.

Hmmmm. I must admit this was truly a disappointment for me. After reading the reviews and excited about my Yelp food selection while I vacation this was a firework that just fizzed. The wait is extremely long with no seating, just a nasty dirty floor.  The service was just a bad as the seating. Once we were finally seated, 15 minutes later someone comes with water.  Then we waited another 25 minutes before someone came to take our drink order. Not passing up the chance for him not to come back for another 15-20 minutes I placed our order at the same time. 20 minutes later the server brings our drinks.   Needless to say, the hubby and kids were starving and lost complete patience while waiting for the food.  The food was slightly cool when were received it so overall, for the service I have to give Yolk 10 thumbs down. (That is two thumbs per family member.)  My hubby's food was actually pretty good, his omelet, though cool, was cooked perfectly.  My pancakes on the other hand were less than specular, I ended up leaving them and I truly dislike wasting food.  My eggs were rubber like and cold. My kids had the Oreo pancakes.  They actually love the pancakes stuffed and topped with Oreo crumbles.  Yolk was very generous with Oreo crumbles which was a big hit with the kiddos.   All in all, I believe that this is a tourist place and definitely a hang out for college students in the area.  If you have the time and the ability, there are far more better places to have breakfast in Chi-town and you can pass this one up.

The Orange & Strawberry of he Tour de France French Toast was awesome. I didn't care for the other two Tour de France selections though; Banana Nut & Lemon Poppy Seed.  The Banana Fosters Creme was awesome also.
Great place for breakfast! Very popular on weekends. Great food and very good price!

Went here Sunday morning before heading back to Houston and the food was great. There was a variety of unique items to choose from but I tried the banana nut bread french toast topped with bananas and a side of peanut butter. It was awesome! The only drawback about this place was the wait (45 min) but it was well worth it.

Great food and fantastic service! This was my first time trying Yolk after it has been recommended to me multiple times and it definitely exceeded my expectations.  Sunday morning was quite busy and we were told to expect a wait of 45 minutes for 3 people, but they got us in after about 20 minutes. Our waitress was very helpful, polite and attentive.  My brother ordered the eggs Benedict which are supposedly the best in the city, he said they were good but nothing too special. I really enjoyed their Huevos Rancheros; all the ingredients tasted fresh and the portions were huge! They even let me substitute in more expensive ingredients (avocado) for free. I would definitely recommend their homemade strawberry orange juice too.  Overall, it's excellent food and surprisingly good service for such a busy place.

I was in town for a conference and had limited time for breakfast or brunch. Since we were staying at the Hilton this was a short walk from the hotel. We were a party of 5 and were quickly seated. Our waiter was a bit overwhelmed, he couldn't seem to keep up with his tables. We had an accident at our table - water spilled and it took him 15 minutes to keep napkins to clean up the water. We tried to do it ourselves, but the bathrooms had no paper towels. When the waiter finally returned, we had moved away from the table as to not get soaked from the water. Then, the waiter cleaned the floor first. We just didn't understand this thinking.Fast forward, my food was great. I ordered the shrimp benedict because it was a twist on an old classic. Yum! The other members of my party were satisfied with the meals as well. My only negative comment about the food was they put everything on one plate..including the fruit next to the hot potatoes & hollandaise sauce. Needless to say, I didn't eat the fruit although I would have loved to on such a hot day in the city.  I enjoyed the meal, but the service was not great. I'd return to give it another try.

This tasty BYOB spot was worth the wait! We killed time by heading over to Trader Joe's to pick up the finest Champagne that $5.99 can buy, and once seated mixed up some fine mimosas with Yolk's fresh squeezed OJ. I ordered one of their specials that was forged in my dreams: pulled pork, mango salsa, mozzerella, and a fried egg on a pretzel roll. Literally all of my favorite things in one sammie, and it did not disappoint. The prices were reasonable and the service was great! She even gave us little to-go cups to take our extra OJ on the road. I firmly believe that brunch is the most important meal of the day, and yolk was a great way to start it off right.

Came here the morning/afternoon after a night out.  It was recommended to me by a few sources.  Let me warn you, do not come here starving because you will have to wait at least 30 minutes for a table unless you know someone.  Which lucky for me, I did and only had to wait about 10 minutes before being seating.  Our server came over shortly after and said hi and asked if we would like any drinks, and we started to browse through the menu.  The place was packed and it took a little time for our server to come back around to grab our order.  I ordered the Pancake Combo and my friend ordered Biscuits and Gravy with fruit on the side. Our meals did not take long to come out, I'd say about 15 minutes.  My combo came with two pancakes, two sausages, two slices of bacon, and eggs, which I had scrambled.  Everything was hot and tasty.  The sausages were huge and delicious, the eggs and bacon were tasty too.  The pancakes though, were not the best.  Don't get me wrong, they were good and I like them, but I'm kind of a pancake snob.  They were not fluffy or light, and just left me wanting a little more from them.   I also snagged a bit of my friends Biscuits and gravy which were very good! Overall I would say that Yolk is a good breakfast joint that anyone can enjoy.  The service is decent and the food is good, and you can enjoy eating your breakfast and catch up with your pals.

Not impressed. I had the eggs benedict, which the menu claims was voted best in Chicago. I think that the only people voting must have been family members of the owner, because they were lackluster at best. I also ordered a side of corned beef hash, and it was straight out of a can.

This is my favorite breakfast place to go to in Chicago. Granted I don't live in Chicago, but I visit often enough where I make it a point to have breakfast/brunch almost every time I come. While the portions are huge, it's how good their food is that makes this place worth coming back. I've had their benedicts (pot roast and traditional), omelettes, frittatas, pancakes, and they're all great. Coffee is average but good early in the morning and you can have as many cups as you want. Strawberry OJ is amazing as others have said. Service is pretty good for how popular the place is. Waits can be long (~1 hour) esp on Sunday morning and there isn't a place to sit to wait unless you go outside. Hopefully they'll get around to using that waiting area space inside more effectively by putting seating there. It's a close walk from the Red Line.

My go to place for sunday brunch in Chicago! It's quite perfectly situated on Michigan Ave, so you can kickstart a fun day downtown by getting a hearty brunch here. Being a super french toast explorer/addict, I highly recommend the "Tour de France". You will love it!

stumbled into this gem after visiting the museum campus peninsula. It's at a convenient location, with a bright and cheery atmosphere. I had their skillet breakfast with turkey/asparagus/mushrooms and a poached egg on top. This is more than enough for one person, delicious tasty meal. Service was prompt and friendly, and a few of the staff members even came by to recommend me their favorite local haunts seeing that I wasn't a local. They also have quite an extensive menu for vegetarians too. Would definitely come back when I'm in town!

Oh my gosh, the portion sizes here are HUGE!!  I ordered an omelet and it came with potatoes and an entree sized portion of pancakes.  The food was good - the pancakes one of our parties ordered were cold (we think b/c they were put out before our eggs were ready), but they took them back and delivered new warm ones right away.  The pancakes were a little dry, but we still really enjoyed our meal.  And did I mention the portions are HUGE?  I finished only half of what was on my plate.

It's byob and it fit nicely in my giving friends the tour of the loop. But I probably won't be back.  The food was fine, but there are way too many places with better brunch options. They also seem to be too busy for their own good, no seats in the Air Conditioned waiting area, and entirely too many 4 tops, which they consistently use for 2 tops.  Our waitress was friendly, besides the fact we never quite had the right number of menus/silverware/cups etc on our table.  Anyways if you need some byob brunch it's really the only reason to go here.

Tourist trap, therefore it's b-u-s-y. Food came out quickly, but the check took a while--so we ended up sitting around waiting a bit for it. Waiter forgot my friend's English muffin, after pointing out that he still needed to get it. And coffee refills were sloww), but these were minor things.  Food was o-k, things were cooked well, but it wasn't anything special (no great seasoning/flavor). I probably wouldn't come here again. Not with other breakfast places so close by.  I found their "Fresh Squeezed Strawberry-Orange Juice" misleading...but I guess they did "squeeze" it out of that gallon jug from the fridge. (Just kidding, it was two jugs, one for strawberry and one for orange juice.)

Delicious, fresh foods. Friendly servers, and multiple convenient locations. I know, it sounds like a generic fast foods commercial, but it really is all of those things. I will remember Yolk for my next trips to Chicago.

Just returned from our second visit to Yoke at 355 E Ohio Street (corner of Grand & McClurg) and I must say that we're very happy with this find! Each of us had the Dublin Pot Roast sandwich which was rich, flavorful and grilled light and crispy. While enjoying the sandwich, I was thinking that a ramekin of the mushroom cabernet sauce for dipping might be nice, and then who should appear but our friendly server! It was almost spooky! Okay not really... Now, I was expecting the sauce to be gravy-esque tinged with red and bits of mushroom, but it turned out to be more like a French-dip au jus - still nice to have, though. Choice of fries, onion chips, fruit or slaw and for me when fried onion is available, nothing else has a chance! It's a good thing nobody is checking my cholesterol anytime soon!  The dining area is airy and open but, acoustically "live", so it was a little loud. Overall the service was efficient and friendly and the menu is extensive. On our last visit, I had the Black and Blue Steak Caesar Salad which I remember as just great. So we'll have to return real soon! No Yoke!

Line can be a little long, but i think thats a good sign. Good crowd especially on saturdays. If you're looking for breakfast food at 2pm. Perfect spot, the crowd is damn near absent and they close at 3pm, so even better.. The food is on point and not too commercialized (yet) as they open more and more locations....Price is on point. You'll enjoy breakfast here...

We were lucky to only have to wait 10 min this fathers day! Its usually a long wait since all the tourist like to eat on Michigan. My friend got the eggs Benedict since they said they were known for them, but I've had better... I got the big skillet and they give you a healthy portion of sausages! Every dish is so large! Mine came with pancakes or toast. Pancakes dusted with some powdered sugar was the way to go.  You absolutely need too get the feedbag squeezed orange strawberry juice! I wish they gave free refills BC it was so nice and refreshing!! Next time I'll try the omelette!

I have been here a couple of times, and I have never been disappointed by the food! Granted, on weekend mornings there is always a long wait, but I do think they do a good job of trying to get you in as fast as they possibly can.  Having read other yelp reviews, I tried their strawberry orange juice (fresh squeezed, the only orange juice I will drink) and it is AMAZING!  the food is HUGE portions for a very reasonable price, and I always leave with another meal in my hand..:) definitely has become a favorite brunch place!

I got the Blue cheese bacon spinach tomato frittata.  I am not a big raw tomato fan. So I asked if they were cut large or small. He assured me that they were diced and cooked.  Everything was good except the tomatoes which were hardly cooked(enough for me). So I picked around them.   He enjoyed his Eggs Benedict.  Was a nice place.

long wait before seating as expected.. service was pretty slow .. ordered the Eggs Benedict , chocolate strawberry pancakes, and a glass of orange juice... orange juice was more on the sour side then sweet.. the Eggs Benedict was pretty decent and the pancakes was just average.. there are just far better options for breakfast places around the neighborhood then yolk.. for the wait and price I'm paying, i would expect better service and food...

We go here all the time as I live super close- like above it. 1) price- I think price is pretty fair. It's reasonable and you get a good amount of food. Eggs Benedict is around $15 I think. 2) quality- as other reviews put it, the food is good. We usually get a version of eggs benedict and something sweet like waffles. 3) quantity- for the price you pay, you get a decent amount of food and this is coming from a guy that eats a lot (once ate and drank 16 lbs of food and water in a day) 4) atmosphere- cute with pictures of fried eggs all over the place 5) staff- nice Also if you go during a mad rush time be sure to listen to your name because if you leave you may get called and lose your spot.

I'm sorry, but I'd like to know where you can find larger portions of (genuinely tasty breakfast) for less money in a big city?  I feel like half of the 2 and 3 star reviews mention the price/quantity, and I'm frankly baffled.  My ~8 dollar order of huevos rancheros was HUGE. We're talking multiple corn tortillas, 3 eggs, what seemed like a 1/4 lb of chorizo and potatoes. Oh, and it tasted darn good.  The coffee was a little pricey, but the free refills made it worthwhile.  Get here very early, very late, or be willing to wait. But if you need to fuel up for the day, or tide yourself over until a very late dinner, this is the way to go.  Although I was in from out of town, I'll be sure to keep this on my list for casual breakfast options in Chicago.

I love Yolk. Love it. It only gets three stars because of location and the service due to the location. This location just isn't my favorite. Since this location is on Michigan Ave., it attracts more tourists than I would like to encounter during my breakfast/brunch hour. and because its so packed and busy, the servers look a bit frazzled trying to get everything out and done right. Be patient when you venture to this locale. If you go to this location, be prepared to wait for a table, especially if you have a large party. I was with a group of seven people and we waited about 45 minutes to an hour. By the time we were seated I was starving, which was good, because the food is dabombdotcom. Portions are large, I would suggest sharing except they charge you two extra bucks to share. Might as well order a dish and split between those in your party. You won't regret it. You'll be trying everything and its all good. I had the iron man omelet with pancakes and hash browns while trying everybody else's dishes at my table. Good thing it was family, I think some of my friends wouldn't be so willing to share! The food is that good. I also tried the waffles, the cinnamon french toast and a crepe of some sort. All delicious. You'll be good and full that you will have enough energy to see all of the Chicago sights. Go to yolk! You won't be disappointed!

I enjoy Yolk breakfast. They have a great menu and the food is well prepared. With that being said I have to give my experience with THIS location 2 stars. The problem: When arriving I was expecting a 45 minute wait. This isn't the issue. The issue is the waiting area is a walled off separate part of the building. The AC units don't blow into this part of the building and one whole wall is nothing but east facing windows. Needless to say it was extremely hot. Also, they did not have ANY chairs in the waiting area. What you are left with is a group of 30+ hot, ornery people sitting on the floor or standing for 45 minutes. This is not a great way to start the experience.   When we were called and given a table it was another 20 minutes before a waitress arrived to get our drink order. After spending 45 minutes baking in the sun I was in desperate need for something to drink. I know they were busy. I didn't need my food right away but a chance to order something to drink would have been appreciated.  After getting a beverage the waitress disappeared for another 20 minutes. So in reality the wait time was more like 1.5 hours.  The waitress, Iris, couldn't have been less personable or friendly. She was stressed which I get being as busy as it was but that isn't my fault as the customer. Hire more people or get servers that perform better under pressure.  The food came which was delicious. I had the Eggs Benedict and they were great. I am not done with Yolk as a company I just wouldn't go to that location again unless it was on an off time and not in the summer.
Cute name, bright cheery atmosphere with friendly servers. Got the Canadian Eggs Benedict - good portions, ordinary flavors. 3.5 stars.

We recently visited Chicago for a long weekend, and Yolk was our go-to breakfast spot every morning.  Yes.  It's that good. They've got a lot of fancy-schmancy stuff on the menu, and every thing we tried was great.  The purist in me, though, most appreciated the simple stuff they did so well.  The pancakes (just the regular old pancakes) were some of the best I've ever had.  Fluffy and hot and not too sweet.  I also had the oatmeal (twice), and they offered a number of options to jazz things up, like fresh berries and raisins.   It gets busy early, so, unless you don't mind waiting in line, plan on arriving early.  Because my kids are for some reason constitutionally incapable of sleeping past 6:30am, we had no problem getting a table.   Because it's so busy, the service can be a little slow, but, for us at least, our servers were always friendly and accommodating (even if a little frazzled at times).  The layout of the space is very open, and even when it's crowded it doesn't feel cramped.   Cops apparently love this place.  There were always about a dozen of them scattered throughout.  So if you're a fugitive, or if cops just make you nervous, beware.  You might want to wear a disguise.

Red Velvet French Toast.  Need I say more?!  I don't know if it's just me, but everything in Chicago is just exponentially bigger!   The portions here were HUGE!
