Enjoyed Yolk multiple times and love the California Omelet.  Actually, it's the only thing I've ever ordered.  It is absolutely humongous and could easily feed two.  If you take it home for leftovers, remember it has guacamole which doesn't reheat very well. Service has always been pleasant. If you can get a booth, you're in luck.  The table configuration is a bit tight and a times annoying (maybe cause I'm not a morning person). For a table of 2, I've never had to wait more than 10-minutes.

I live next door to Yelp. We've gone there frequently, but that is ending. After yet another terrible experience today we're done. The food is good enough, the place is big, and the service is typically fine...just so you know I'm not unbalanced. Three key reasons we're done with Yolk: 1) Air Conditioning: Seems its permanently "being fixed". I walked in today and put in a reservation for two and a baby. I asked if the A/C was working because it was hot by the door. The hostess woman said "As far as I know" without looking me in the eye. I took her word, but when we got our table it was sweltering hot. I don't care that the A/C was broken, frankly. It happens. But when someone comes in and asks for a table with a baby, TELL THEM THE TRUTH IF THE AC ISN'T WORKING. Neither of us was happy when my child spent the next half hour screaming in discomfort. Terrible for a "family place".  2) Coffee-The Lies Continue: We go to Yolk almost every weekend. Every time, we order coffee and realize there's no Splenda, Sweet & Low, or Equal. Only Truvia sweetener. Apologies if you like Truvia. I don't. It tastes bad to me. I am of the opinion that that is why 100% of other places offer splenda/sweet&low/equal. When you ask for some Sweet & Low, EVERY SINGLE TIME the waiter is instructed to tell you they don't have it, only Truvia. EVERY TIME, when you push back, they say "let me go see if we have anything else". EVERY TIME they come back with Sweet & Low. It gets to be overwhelming to have to go thru this charade every single visit. As a restaurant analyst, I can tell you for sure that messing with people's coffee is a one way street. I'm either going to remember to bring my own splenda every time, or start going somewhere else. Guess which one is likely to happen? 3) General Lack of Customer Service: In general, the wait staff is nice. Except when they have been trained to lie to you (air conditioning, sweetener, etc). The food is mediocre, but acceptable. Add a 30 minute minimum wait (usually 45-60 mins) and you can probably do equally as well elsewhere. Add some incident at almost every visit (like AC or lies about basic items like sweetener) and you can definitely have a lower-BS occasion elsewhere. We're also usually seated next to a container for dirty dishes so our baby has to hear glass crashing into it next to him the whole trip, or in the middle of some busy aisle where a stroller doesn't fit. Again, its not their fault that we have a kid. But just tell us if you can't accommodate us with a table that won't be in your way and we'll go elsewhere.  In general, this place has potential to be a nice breakfast place worthy of your business. But the constant lack of care or customer service basics really makes Yolk a bad decision for breakfast in the South Loop. I would avoid this place if you can.

This place was running one of the biggest scams I've ever encountered at a restaurant when I visited there on July 2.  Let me explain.  On July 2, it was 92 degrees, with the humidity it was hitting 102.  After walking to Yolk I was excited to get inside in the air conditioning.  Guess what, for some reason they don't air condition the area where you wait; BUT, don't worry, if you are thirsty and need to cool down from standing in the non-air conditioned waiting area of the  restaurant you can BUY a $1.50 bottled water or a $2.00 sports drink.  We asked for tap water, AND guess what they wont give you a cup with ice and tap water BECAUSE *drumroll*....... then they couldn't sell you $1.50 bottles of water!!!  Believe it or not, it was actually cooler sitting outside in the heat than it was standing in that restaurant  on that day. We stayed to eat here (because it was 1230am and I hadnt eaten all day and didnt want to find another place in the heat).  The service was sub-par.  Our water glasses were consistently empty (probably because we were drinking too fast as a result of the dehydration we suffered from not being able to shell out another $1.50 each for more water during our wait for a table).   The food did come fast; but it was nothing to write home about.  I've had better benedict's than the South of the Border that I ordered and the pancakes were pancakes.... If I could award a least ethical restaurant award it would go to Yolk.
Yolk has pretty standard breakfast food that's served up in a bright and cheery restaurant.  If you're looking for good typical brunch food, head here.
Portions are huge!  Food came out of kitchen quickly.  Loved it!  Large menu and the variations on Eggs Benedict are yummy!

Meh.. It's just average at best.  Please don't waste your time waiting like we did for more than 1 hour!  Why was there a long line?   Four of us ate extremely average different menu entries.  Not a fan.

If there's one thing I can't live without, it's an egg. So, when I first heard about this breakfast joint called Yolk, I knew it was a must try. Thankfully, I wasn't disappointed. Like most breakfast places, Yolk has a very casual vibe, and service is quick and friendly. Just a glance at the menu and I knew we had to try Hey Ricky: a Spanish omelette with chorizo, avocado, jalapeno, and most importantly melted jack and cheddar cheese. We also ordered the Eggs Florentine and Pecan Waffle. The Pecan Waffle was topped with sliced bananas and a caramel sauce. Everything was perfectly flavored, and nothing was too sweet. The omelette and Eggs Florentine were also amazing, but nothing I haven't had before. The combination of eggs, cheese, salsa, and sour cream has to be one of the best invention ever made. I can honestly eat that for breakfast, lunch, and dinner. If you like savory breakfast foods, you won't be disappointed with Yolk!!
First time going there this weekend.  The place is noisy, crowded, and service was really slow.   I will not be going back

Eggs Benedict, South of the Border Benny's, Crepes, The Farm House biscuits and gravy... where can you get so much good food for such a decent price? This is one of my favorite brunch places in the city, the food and the service are top notch.  It does get busy during the typical weekend brunch time, but they get everyone in and out fairly quickly. I prefer stopping in during the week of course to have a little quiet with my big brunch.

Very busy and therefore slow. Bacon was too crispy for my liking but the crepes were something to write home about :) the selection of fresh fruit was great as well. Expect a wait for seating as well as your food but it is worth it.

My roommate and I were in Chicago this past weekend and Yolk was recommended to us buy our concierge. She offered her card and told us to give that to our host at Yolk in order to receive priority seating.  The Sunday crowd was in full swing when we arrived. We walked in, gave our names, and flashed the business card. I suppose it worked...we were seated within 15 minutes, and at a booth no less. The food was good...not amazing, but good. They have several types of bread that they use for french toast. I ordered a french toasted cinnamon roll...it was delicious actually. Coffee was decent, and the service was friendly and efficient.

Three Words: Strawberry Orange Juice!!!!!  I've been to Yolk a few times, but I'm finally getting around to writing a review. I love the fact that you can can get healthy options to your breakfast. A side of fruit, egg whites and etc. Its a way to have a big breakfast, but feel less guilty about it. Lol!  The best times to go are during the week! Weekends will be crowded. Decent prices, for lots of food and in a great location! Yolk is alright with me!  Oh, try their cinnamon buns! They're delicious!

Amazing eggs benedict. Amazing skillets. Nice service, but irritatingly slow if it's during rush hour and you're hungry. Be prepared to go somewhere else for an hour on a Sunday morning. But, it's well worth it. Amazingly delicious.

Good breakfast spot, with a huge menu. I love breakfast and I would compare this place to ihop, all the food is really good but there is nothing on the menu that jumps out at you for being unique to their menu. If your in the mood for a good place for pancakes, eggs and bacon this is a good spot.
Great food! Mediocre service :(

Meh, overated, I heard great things about their french toast so I had to try it. But it was just a normal piece of thin sourdough with too little custard soaked into the bread.  I also tried their signature eggs benedict and that was good, nice creamy holandaise, poached egg was a little rough around the edges but the yolk was perfectly runny. The canadian bacon was cut weird thicker on one side making for uneven salty to creamy to bread ratio in some areas. The english muffin was fresh and moist, that was a real plus.  I was also disappointed when there was no mimosa or other breakfast cocktails, can't call yourself a proper brunch place. Overall I was not impressed, and definitely would not want to wait 45 min+ in order to eat here.

This is one of my favorite restaurants in the city. Great food, great service. Gets very crowded during brunch  "rush hour"- but worth the wait if you have the time.  During the week there is not much of a wait and you can be in and out- stuffed and happy!

Yes, everyone knows yolk for brunch is a great idea. EVERYONE including TONS of tourists in the summer time so be prepared to wait a bit esp on weekends. Inside, bright and cheerful, a customer might find him/herself enjoying a BYOB mimosa or bloody (recommended). As for the menu, I recommend splitting a sweet and a savory item with a friend to take proper advantage of their long list of treats. Service is great. The taste can be a little bland at times, but otherwise recommended especially if you are new in town!
Long wait during peak hours. Love the variety of breakfast items. You can get anything you want.

Great, great, great food, reasonable prices - this place would even be worth the 25+ min weekend wait if the service wasn't so so dreadful..... Our brunch turned into an 1.5 hour ordeal in which our waiter ignored us most the time. After our food was delivered he didn't come back to check on us our give us our bill - after 50 min we had to hunt down another waitress just to get our check. Our section (which had 2 servers) was using team work to pass extra silverware, ketchup, ect back and forth while the severs ignored us and chatted away (in our view)! The bottom line is the food is really great just GET IT TO GO!

Everything about Yolk is good. Not great but really solid for a restaurant of this size. There are not enough brunch places in the S. Loop so it is nice to have a reliable place. However the food isn't terribly inspired. They try to make up for this with ginormous portions but they might be better served by focusing on fresher ingredients. I've had three different omelets here - all good but not terribly inspired flavor combinations.  A solid S. Loop option.

I ate at Yolk a few weeks ago and had an overall good experience.  The food was great, and after all, that's what I went there for! The beginning of our adventure started off a little rocky though..  We got there sometime around 10:30 on a Sunday.  We were expecting a wait, so we weren't startled when they told us it would be 45-60 minutes.  The thing that did annoy us, however, was the annoying host that was working.  To put it simply, he was rude and did not know how to take charge and direct the crowd of people to stand in the right place.  I was okay with waiting, but the guy was REALLY getting on all of our nerves. We were eventually seated and HUNGRY!  I got the corned beef hash with a poached egg and the potatoes and it was deliciousss.  Everything on the menu looked so good.  I need to go back soon and keep on trying different things.  My mouth is watering just thinking about it!

If you're visiting Chicago and looking for a great place to have breakfast near the the Loop and Grant Park, I don't think there is a better place. My mom would come to visit me while I attended school, and she not only remembered, but requested it whenever she would visit. What a great place, with great food and an excellent morning atmosphere. Start your day off right!

We ate here on a Thursday morning.  It's on Michigan Avenue, about 3 blocks from our hotel.  We ate there around 9:00am.  There was a light crowd, probably because most of the city was at work.  The service here is very good.  The place is hip/contemporary (for a "breakfast place"), but we didn't feel out of place (even though we were in shorts & t-shirts).  The coffee and OJ are delicious!  The portions are big and the food arrived quickly.  I ordered, are you ready for this, the red velvet french toast!  They cut 2 slices of red velvet cake (loaf style...like a jelly roll, but instead of jelly...it's cream cheese frosting), and they batter them in egg bath and cook them on a griddle.  They're served with eggs, fruit, bacon & sausage.  They also give you syrup & powdered sugar for the main portion, but you don't need it...the frosting in the middle is all you need!  It was a great meal and so much that I couldn't finish it all.  Everything was cooked very well.  The sausages were plump & flavorful (these are big breakfast sausages too...no mini links here).  You get what you pay for at Yolk, but it's totally worth it.  My meal was around 9 or 10 bucks (plus tax, tip & beverages).  I would go again tomorrow if I was in Chicago.  It's a great place to get a great bite to eat...just show up hungry!

Really delicious! I love their strawberry OJ and they have the best corned beef hash! It gets so crowded during peak times on the weekends, but if you catch it early enough this place is a great south loop option for breakfast!

Ok, I heard so many great things about this place I had to try it... but if I'd known how long the wait was going to be, I might have packed an overnight bag!!   The set up for the people waiting for a table was RIDICULOUS!! Packed like sardines in a small alcove in the front of the restaurant?? We waited for over an hour for our table, but when we were finally seated, the food was great!! The service was so-so, but I blame that on the fact that the waitress was just TOOOO busy to give us much attention!   I would recommend this place for breakfast, but don't go hungry or if you're in a hurry!

We started our annual trip to Chicago for the Restaurant show at our favorite breakfast spot, Yolk.   They simply never let us down.  Huge portions, good service and very tasty.  You can't miss with the Eggs Bene or the Zamboni crepes.  This place is so good we go every single morning for breakfast and actually rented a condo right around the corner so we start out day right before the show every day.  Just about as good as it gets.

I work and live close by, so I generally eat here once every two weeks if not more. You just can't beat the quality of food. The wait can be a pain at times, but if you get there early enough (8-9, it's breakfast time anyway!) you can be seated within 15 minutes usually.  I have loved everything I've had here, but the Texas Fajita Omelette is my favorite. Quality ingredients, and some of the best quac I've ever had.  Go and enjoy!

The food here is great and they give you a lot so expect left overs or head over with a really empty stomach to fill. This place is always packed so expect a wait and it can get pretty loud so conversation can be hard some times.

You better come here hungry! The portions are HUGE, and I'm not complaining. But if you're not a big eater, among two people you can definitely share a plate.  As we walked in we were greeted by a good looking hostess who showed us to our booth immediately. The place is big and looks really new. The staff friendly and our meals came fast! I ordered the Texas omelettes with egg whites. I think they put a little too much chicken, usually I'm all for the more meat the better but it took away from the taste. I could barely get a taste of the grilled onions and green peppers that were also in this omelette. And also when I order an omelette I want to taste eggs. It was just stuffed with grilled chicken that I felt like I was eating a plate of chicken. But the potatoes were tasty and the coffee really good as well. I would go here again but not order the Texas omelette. I do really like how you can substitute for egg whites with no extra charge.

Wonderful breakfast food! I had a custom skillet. Delicious! Diverse menu & I love that egg beaters & egg whites are available at no extra charge. The kids menu isn't a-typical, either. My daughter LOVED the Smores pancakes.

I left feeling very satisfied. Yes, the wait was long...close to 45 min, but well worth the wait. I had the Countryside Skillet, while my boyfriend had the Works Omelette. The portions were large and very filling. We both got about 3/4 thru our dishes.  1st time there, won't be the last!
Breakfast doesn't get better than Yolk! Great coffee, and the cinnamon roll french toast is out of this world (brace yourself for sugar shock) but is it worth it!
Meh. I don't really get the hype at this place.  I mean, it's cute... the food is pretty good... but I am not ready to stand in line for this place, nor am I dying to go back either.

Whenever we go to Chicago we stay at the Chicago Hilton and walk several blocks to Yolk for breakfast. The four of us had a wonderful breakfast on the Monday after Easter.  Like the other reviews said, Yolk can be busy especially with the locals from the numerous trendy south loop high rises nearby. So we sleep in a bit then go here after the rush - about 9:30am.   We were seated fast and had orders quickly.  My order had 2 mistakes which were fixed in under 1 minute and they also gave us a chocolate crepe as a comp.  The waiters/waitresses really move here.  I had a large multitude of fresh fruit on my plate which unlike many diners was very fresh. Synopsis - once you are seated food is hot, fresh and fast.

Food is always good. Crowded during the weekend rush but overall great service.  Everyone is super friendly. Once you're seated it doesn't take long to be served. You'll never feel like you're being pushed out the door after finishing your meal. Yolk has an extensive menu that even the pickiest palate will find something to make your taste buds dance and tummy say yummmm.  Everyone in your group will be satisfied because if you don't want breakfast no worries have a burger in the morning. Don't forget to have the freshly squeezed orange juice. The OJ always tastes so good like you're biting into a juicy ripe orange...never tart always tastes like the oranges are in season. Fresh blueberries were firm and ripe never in some artificial syrup to masquerade the taste of berries. I love fresh berries and this always hits the stop.  If you have a hard time finding street parking there's a public parking lot right next door for $8.00.  I'm always satisfied when I leave.

Came here on a Sunday morning, at about 8:30am.  We saw my sister begin the Hot Chocolate race, and then while she was running her behind off in that race, my parents, brother-in-law and niece and nephew went to have a hearty breakfast.  Works for me. We got in and got a table in about 5 minutes.  The place was PACKED.  Families, 20- somethings, seniors, young moms, couples, college kids with their parents, every type of person was there.  Even a few who were dining along. There was a great kids menu with really AWESOME, what- kids'- dreams- are- made- of selections such as Oreo Pancakes, caramel french toast, etc.  DO NOT bring a child here is you want them to have oatmeal with fresh fruit, because they will get an eyeful of what other people are eating and have a meltdown. The breakfast menu is huge, and playful, and lots of options, and servings are large and very filling.  Keep in mind that because the crowds here are so large, your waitress/ server is probably not bubbly and sweetsy- they're just trying to get everyone served, and the orders  accurate. They're just fairly no-nonsense here. Once we were seated, it looked like the line went from 5 minute wait to 50 minute wait.  The line went out the door and around the corner. If you find yourself along South Michigan Ave. in the morning- stop in here.  It's a "wow" breakfast!

Tried an egg frittata, an omelette, and the French toast. I normally love anything breakfast without question, but this place really turned me off with the egg dishes which I didn't think would happen with a place named Yolk. I was halfway done and had to push my plate away. The service is very friendly and the French toast was amazing, especially with their homemade syrup. Good coffee too. Probably will not return here though.

I'm an eggs benedict fiend. I drove all the way to Chicago from Ann Arbor to eat a decent plate of eggs benny and this place delivered!  The Benedict deconstructed:  About the meat to bread ratio: Perfectly balanced! Canadian bacon slice wasn't too skimpy or too thick, it was just right.    About the hollandaise sauce: fully made from scratch and ever-so-slightly tart with a hint of tabasco.  Eggs: poached to perfection. Whites are firm, but oh, how the yolk drizzles out!  P.S. They could work on the home fries; they were kinda *meh.* And the fruit? That's an added bonus and guilt reliever when you're ingesting your week's worth of cholesterol, but seriously, put it in a bowl or something--I don't like hollandaise touching anything healthy on my plate.   P.S.S. Eggs Benedict is one of the best meals on earth. There's a reason why James Bond constantly orders it in the novels.  Man's got taste!

Lots of options and the servings are huge.  I had the California Omelette was stuffed for most of the day.  If you can get past the wait - I'd definitely check this place out.  Their pancakes are next on my list...

This place is to die for! The menu is crazy good - tons of selections and stuffed french toast that is out of this world.  It is a crazy long wait on the weekends, but if you have the time and plan ahead - it is totally worth it!

I was just there today and my opinion has not changed. I wanted to get the specialty pancakes with my omelette but there really aren't very many options for those specialty pancakes. the food was good but the service was pretty bad again. the server came over one time to ask if everythings okay and before i could answer and ask if she could bring me something she was already by another table. she also did not seem to listen, when she asked my dad if he would like ketchup for the skillet he said no but she brough it out for him anyway. Whats the point in asking if you're going to do it either way?
I love breakfast food. This is better than Bongo room (Sloop) that's a block away.

Dear Yolk,  I love you and your sunshiney goodness. I cannot believe that it's taken me over two years to Yelp about Yolk.  I was actually just going on to update my review, only to realize I never wrote one.  Yolk is my go to brunch spot - my absolute fav and a must have spot for any and all guests.  Sure the wait seems daunting when you walk in to a crowd of people, but they move tables quickly here (and never in a rush you out the door way either).  Opt for counter service because you'll get seated sooner.  I have to disagree with Yelpers about this being a tourist trap, it's not - you're likely to run in to some neighbors enjoying the morning.  But if you want to avoid potentially touristy crowds, that's fine, more Yolk for me :) Yolk has an amazing menu, but my husband and I usually stick to the french toasts because they are so delicious!  I love the Tour de France so I can have a little of everything.  He loves the banana bread with nutella.  Sometimes we'll add an apple muffin or some sausage, but usually the french toast is enough.  Their coffee is delicious too!  It must be a Latin-American blend because it has a nice nutty flavor.  As far as I'm concerned, you can't beat the prices either.  Everything seams priced fairly.  If you're super hungry, order the omelets or crepes and eggs - HUGE portions that I can never, ever finish.

The prices are reasonable, good coffee, and alot of menu options for vegetarians. I really enjoyed the atmosphere and the location is nice. The food came out really fast and I got the biggest fruit plate ever for 3.49, which was delicious. I got the cheesy egg sandwich and it was very tastey. All around recommended and I will go back for sure the next time I'm in the area.

Yolk is a place that keeps things classy while offering a menu full of special and simple meals at a very good price. It caters to the Sunday brunchers and the weekday neighbors, with eggstravant (shoot me but I had too) choices and simple ones to spare. It's bustling and busy, but you get your good service. You'll wait for a while if you come in at rush hour, but you won't be cramped into a corner or sitting in the lap of someone else's fiance while you try to enjoy a good meal.--Spacious still, booths and tables alike.  You won't be surprised when I say that Yolk's forte is its eggs. One of the few restaurants whose cooks deliver at the request of an over-medium egg, and make beautifully shaped poached eggs. Favorites include the benedicts and the skillets. I'm not totally in love with scrambled eggs so when I tell you that the omelettes are okay, that probably means they're pretty good.   But I'm telling you: there's a reason the place is called Yolk. Choose how you want your main dish and then pick your accompaniments accordingly. Pancakes are nice and fluffly. French toast is good too. My only tiny disappointment is that the corned beef hash is from the can, so I'll steer clear from that dish and remain happy with other options.  Yolk offers pretty big portions and manages to have healthy options too. There's a good range of a lunch menu as well. Come to Yolk, for the love of eggs!-- or at least to pick up those cute sillybandz on your way out.

Yes, there always a long wait for breakfast especially on weekends. And yes you have to get there real early to avoid that. But that's a very good sign that you've made a good choice for breakfast.  The coffee was fresh, the omlettes were well-made and the toast was just perfect. And not to mention, the numerous choices for jams and juices. The service was quick and friendly and we were done with the entire meal in less than 20 mins on a busy Sunday morning.  Again, if long lines are like a plague to you then get there early. Ideally before 9:30.

Pros: Huge portions, affordable prices, everything I've had is good (veggie skillet, two eggs, cinnamon roll).  Cons: Huge portions, long waits on the weekends, wish they were open during dinner. If you want to go on the weekend, try the location close to Navy Pier.  Not as convenient to pub trans and parking can be a little spotty but you definitely won't get quoted an hour for 2.

I went here with two friends on a snowy/rainy Saturday around 1:30 PM. The place was packed but the wait didn't exceed 15 minutes. The place is very organized and clean, and the staff are very friendly. I ordered the huevos rancheros and I found it very refreshing as I've never tried Tex-mex brunch. The jalapenos were mildly spicy and I like how they topped it with an over-easy egg.

Take a good look at the picture because you won't see it that empty when they are serving. The food is amazing. Chocolate strawberry pancake is heaven on a plate. The wait was long, the people were close, but the food was worth it.

By far my favorite pplace to grab lunch. While a sit down restaurant I have never had to wait for a seat (I don't recommend going on the weekends if you don't want to wait). The wait staff is cordial and checks in but pretty much leaves you to your own devices which suits me fine and I've spent time there doing studying for class. Everytime I go I think about ordering something different but I never do. I ALWAYS order the eggs benedict and have never been disappointed. The poached eggs, whcih can easily be overcooked, have always been cooked perfectly and the Hollandaise sauce tastes fantastic. Their potatoes are a perfect complement to the meal. I get a side of bacon and a coke and spend about 15.00 before the tip so I don't go to often due to the fact I'm a poor college student but it's by far my favorite spot to grab lunch between classes.

I love love love breakfast!!!!!!!!!!! It's my favorite meal anytime of the day. I really want to give Yolk 5 stars because for me the food is good and not overpriced. The caveat? The service. The service could be better. I have been there several times and I had a nice waitress only once! She was perfect-not too attentive, refilled my coffee just about on cue, and she didn't try to rush me because it was busy. Everyone else is always aloof and in a huddle talking amongst themselves. And what's up with the guy at the checkout? He is always just -I don't know- not acting as if he works in a people oriented place. Even my daughter was turned off and she's the one who is always telling me to just relax because it's not that serious. It is if you want people to return.
I'm not a big egg fan, but I do like egg-white fritatas. Label it Mediteranean, and I'm sold! The breakfast rush is insane, but the food and service make it so worth it!

My take on Yolk is that it's pretty much a fancy diner. That's not a bad thing because it's clean, lively, and the service is fast. I ordered the huevos racheros which weren't that good. I can only blame myself for ordering tex-mex here. The service was good and the waitress we had was pretty cool. I'll definitely come back if I'm in the area but may stick to an omelet or pancakes.

So it was a Sunday morning and i should know better but I couldnt help myself I just love this place.  Jam packed with about a 30 min wait but still worth it.  Sat at the counter and had an awesome server named Victoria.  Made us laugh and gave great service.  No Bongo room for us. Good stuff.

Yolk.  Your cinnamon bun and I had a brief tryst this morning and I will hope you dear to my heart forever. Your menu looks fantastic.   I was not impressed with your omelet. Three and a half.  Rounded up.

11 am saturday with rainy/snowy dreary weather? 30 minute wait for two! this place definitely is bumpin, even though there was a ton of people waiting up front, it was very organized, and the hostess was very friendly. i love the different coffee creamers, hazelnut, french vanilla and caramel macchiato.. yum! the strawberry orange juice is great too! i ordered the santa fe frittata. the jalapenos were very spicy but a perfect kick to the skillet of avocado, bacon, onion and potatoes. the salsa was great too, but you have to eat this quick cause when it gets cold, the 3 cheeses on top gets really hard and all the juices start to come out making it really watery. instead of getting toast and pancakes, i upgraded to french toast for i believe $1.49, they were superb. my boyfriend ordered the countryside skillet which was a lot better, the gravy was so flavorful and rich.  my coffee cup was always filled with coffee, fast and friendly service, definitely will be back for brunch! and plus, i took one of the silly rubber bands that is to resemble a yolk i guess, it adds a great touch to this fun restaurant.
There is nothing special about yolk. Potatoes were oversalted. I got a scrammbler that had way too much avocado and little flavor. The one star was for the pancakes that were good.

I ventured down to this Yolk location due to it's proximity to the auto show. This was my second trip to a Yolk overall but my first time to this location. I chose one of their skillets with a side of fresh fruit. The fruit was extremely delicious with an assortment of grapes, melon and pineapple. This paired extremely well with my skillet of turkey sausage, cheese and spinach. Overall, the food was exceptional and came out fast even though the place was packed on a Sunday morning. I would definitely recommend this place to anyone who is looking for a quality breakfast and doesn't mind a little bit of a wait. Even if you have to wait, you can grab some of their fresh coffee to drink in the waiting area.

Mmm, Yolk.  I want to be your best friend.  I want to live right next door to you so that I can go every morning.  Sadly, I can not afford to live off of Michigan Ave, so I will have to visit instead for now! The food here is unbelievably good- fresh, well-cooked, amazing baked goods/pastries baked in house, etc.  You really get the feeling that you could order anything off the menu and it would be equally delicious!  Its pretty popular so I think on weekends there is usually a wait, but trust me, its well worth it!

Stopped by for brunch before seeing Les Miserables. Since it was Sunday, there was a large crowd, but if you're okay with sitting at the bar instead of a table the wait time isn't too bad. Menu is standard brunch fare - I had eaten at one of the other Yolks in the city before (I don't remember what I had), and I wanted to try a different item from their menu. The menu recommended the eggs benedict, so that was what I ordered. It tasted on par with other eggs benedict that I've had before, and it comes with potatoes and fruit (i.e. super filling, food coma-inducing meal). Definitely got my money's worth.

I dont get how someone can rate this below 3 stars. To anyone whose trying to decide on Yolk, if you want to wait for breakfast, you shouldn't come here. On the flip side, if you have to wait for a place, its probably worth it. They have some amazing breakfast pieces. My favorite is uniquely delicious: Pot Roast Eggs Benedict. Two english muffins stacked with slow-cooked pot roast, with two poached eggs and a hearty dose of hollandaise sauce. Oh, and it comes with redskin potatoes and fresh fruit. The menu has a ton of other awesome meals good for breakfast, lunch, and everything in between. With only a handful of breakfast locations in SLoop, expect to wait, and expect Yolk to deliver satisfaction.

This was my first breakfast in Chicago and I loved it.  I am a huge fan of eggs benedict and like to think I am becoming an "expert eggs benedict eater." That said, I have my favorite: The Inn on Coventry in Cleveland. And with THAT said, I have a favorite in Chicago now, too.  The eggs benedict was recommended to me before we got to the restaurant, so for once, I barely looked at a menu, knowing I had to give it a try. I certainly did not regret my decision. While my favorite in Cleveland is perfect diner food, slightly greasier and especially tasty with a side of grits, my new Chicago favorite is a bit lighter.  With the fresh fruit and excellent potatoes, I wasn't able to finish my whole meal, but I left incredibly satisfied and without feeling TOO weighed down.

Grade: A+ With the exception of a lengthy wait for a table, I loved everything about my experience at Yolk. Interesting ambiance, good service, relatively inexpensive... and the food! Oh, the food! My "West Coast Crepes" were absolutely fantastic. Eggs, fresh avocado (in the middle of winter no less), mushrooms, and two kinds of cheese, all within very tasty and light crepes. The fresh fruit was at peek ripeness, despite the time of year, and the pancakes were better than most. This meal, with orange juice, cost only $15 or so including tax and tip. yolk-online.com/menu/yol…

Ambiance for breakfast places is especially important to us and this place is cute, cozy, and definitely cheery!  We love the sunny colors highlighting the spacious interior of the restaurant and the decor is simple and non-cheeeeezy...we've been to too many breakfast places with farm decor or filled with chicken figurines.   We are satisfied every time we visit this place and are especially fans of the corned beef hash and the skillets!  Large, generous portions at a great price...under $10!  Portions are so large that one order usually lasts me 2 or three more breakfasts :) We love this place and always brings a smile to our faces and perks up our mornings!

I love to go to Yolk for brunch! They are have a modern atmosphere, great breakfast, and are moderately priced. I usually get the standard 2 eggs, sausage, potato's, and toast and am able to spend under $10.  It does get a bit crowded on Sunday afternoons when I have been there, but the staff are friendly and they are usually able to move customers through quickly to seating.

My friends and I came here for breakfast the morning after a hangover-esque night out in Wrigleyville. As we walked through the door, we were a little concerned because it was crowded and there were six of us. However, they were able to accommodate us quickly and we got to ordering. I had some fruit, hash browns, and pancakes. The portion sizes were huge. I probably could have made 2-3 breakfasts with what I had to eat. Everything was tasty and done well, and I enjoyed it. The place has a nice contemporary layout, and is a great place to eat on a summer day in the south loop. It's not too expensive, but it costs enough to where I wouldn't make it a stop during my daily routine. Oh, and minus one star for the server we had. He kept giving me the stink-eye because I wouldn't take my sunglasses off inside. I was hungover, dude!

This is about a 3.5 star, but I had to knock it down 1/2 star because the food was OK, but my friend's fork was dirty and there was numerous empty creamer containers mixed in the creamer bowl. The service on the other hand, was on point.  As soon as we were seated the waitress came and offered us coffee. When I went to grab the creamer, I picked up one and saw that it was open and empty. Then I tried to grab the same flavor in the middle of the bowl, again empty. I think I counted a total of about 4 empty creamers, which made think about how much the place pays attention to the trash on the table.  The food... we ordered the eggs Benedict and Florentine. The fruit was fresh and the potatoes were very good. It was seasoned perfectly. I was satisfied with the 2 dishes that we ordered and the service, but was turned off by the empty creamers and dirty fork (even though the waitress brought us a new one as soon as it was brought to her attention). I just think that they should pay attention to the silverware before wrapping it up in the tablecloths.

Meh :T  heard much hype 'bout Yolk and I was sadly disappointed. Realistically 2 1/2 stars.  A huge group of my friends & I finished running the Hot Chocolate 15K in downtown Chicago & worked up a wicked appetite. Debated whether to head back to burbs or stay in city. We finally decided to stick it out in the city & head to Yolk. Of course... it was JAM packed. It didn't help that all the runners congregated to the same location as us. Average wait time: 1hr-1 1/2 hrs. Wooey. So we waited outside...waited some more inside, finally got seated in the back section.  I ordered coffee right away, and believe me when I say this..  I'm no coffee snob, but god dayum..it was nasty. Instant coffee nasty. Down right watery and not fresh. Thought my next cup or third cup would be better, but it was just funky.  For the main entree, I stuck to what my body needed. Hearty portion of carbs, protein, and more protein.    The WORKS omelette: bacon, sausage, ham, mushrooms, onions, tomatoes. Topped with Jack and Cheddar cheeses.      It wasn't bad, but it wasn't anything special.  Service was great despite the madness of the joint. She was attentive and made sure we got everything that we needed.  Since there's an abundant amt of breakfast joints in the city, I don't think I'll be missing out if I don't go back to Yolk.

With our hotel's restaurant under construction, we spent our 2nd morning in Chicago at Yolk for breakfast. This place was packed upon our arrival, which made me feel that it must be a good place for breakfast. There were no tables available right away, but since it was just the two of us we opted for the bar. I ordered coffee, which was in front of me almost immediately after saying the words. The menu at Yolk is pretty overwhelming - crepes, waffles, pancakes, fritattas, "scrambles", traditional breakfasts (eggs + meat + hash browns + toast, etc.), oatmeal, omelettes, pastries, wraps, salads... anything your breakfast-loving heart desires. I ordered an egg white fritatta that included potatoes, chorizo, guacamole, and peppers in the mix. On the side came an english muffin (pancakes or toast were also options). My boyfriend got cinnamon roll french toast... two of his favorite breakfast foods combined, why not? The service was very quick, as the kitchen was ablaze with perpetual motion. My boyfriend's cinnamon roll french toast was basically a cinnamon roll, sliced horizontally into 3 disks, then put in a pan to toast on the bottom side of each. $8 + tax for a freaking cinnamon roll that was cut up and put in a pan? Rip-off. My fritatta was gigantic. For 10 freaking dollars it better have been! However, it was way, way too filling and despite ordering it with egg whites to give it a bit more of a healthy twist, it was dripping with grease. I ate less than 1/3 of it with my english muffin, but was so disgusted at this heavy meal I couldn't bear to eat any more of it. Every bite I felt like I was closer to death. There were two girls next to me who both ordered omelettes and got pancakes on the side. Just the thought of eating so much food makes me sick. The day before we went to a diner called Beef and Brandy, got coffee, OJ, pancakes, and 2 eggs with sausage, hash browns, and toast and spent $10 less than what we did at Yolk. I definitely will NOT be back to Yolk and do not see the appeal of this place. I never thought I'd think IHOP was a step up from anything, but it is when compared to Yolk.

Pancakes, Egg and Meat: and substituted with chocolate strawberry pancake. Supposedly for big eaters but let me say, I demolished that dish. It was delicious. The cool thing is that there's a contemporary feel to the place, while giving you a great diner-like breakfast. I really enjoyed how they let me substitute the pancakes but it wasn't for free. There's a really big line that makes you wonder if it's worth it,  breakfast is one of those meals where I feel it's hard to screw it up. Yolk did not disappoint. I loved how the chocolate strawberry pancakes were not too sweet but they had a very good ratio of fruit to pancake so you don't feel overwhelmed.
Yum!  Fabulous menu selections and food tasted fresh and delicious.  Great wait staff!

This place was down the street from our hotel and seemed promising. There was a line, but it moved very quickly.  Let me just tell you, the portions are HUGE!! You could share if you wanted to. I couldn't even finish half of my crepe. I had the zamboni crepe and it was super yummy! Loved the light texture of the crepe. The ham was nicely cooked and everything came out promptly! The fruit was fresh and a nice touch to the meal.   The service was great! The girl checked on us often and helped out because she knew we were from out of town. Prices are very reasonable considering how much food you get.

I was not impressed with Yolk. As a matter of fact Yolk was Yucky. If you want tasteless omelette's with dry potatoes then this is the place for you. Otherwise I'd steer clear. I think most of the hype is because it's a restaurant on the magnificent mile that's reasonably priced. The pancakes were a little thick but one of the better things they had to offer.

Fabulous breakfast spot on Michigan ave! My husband and I ate there after a night out on the town and were very satisfied. He had delicious french toast and I loved my oatmeal piled high with fresh fruit and nuts! The OJ was fresh and YUM! There are so many delicious sounding items on the menu, I cannot wait to go back and try some more!

A great place if you are craving a scramble or some pancakes.  When I've gone with people since the opening of the new location on Ohio, the eggs have been a little under/over cooked.  Apparently they moved all the good cooks to the new location?  They have really good pancakes that come with fruit and such.  Also, their skillets are my favorite.  If you want a jam-packed breakfast/brunch this is the way to go.
Rudest service ever and it wasn't even a busy time. The food wasn't all that either.

We were walking down michigan on New Years Day in 15 degree weather, freezing...and not even within a block radius of it , a hobo on the street says to us "I know where you're going, You're going to YOLK!". Creepy how he knew, but it must be a popular spot that the hobos sees a general rush of bodies towards that restaurant! We get there and there are SO MANY people waiting, we let the host know we don't mind sitting at the bar so we only ended up waiting for about 20 minutes. They don't take reservations on the weekends. With that said, I really like the meal because 1- I was starving and 2- I love breakfast foods. We opted to only get one dish and share because the portions are HUGE. How can people eat that much for breakfast and not be out of commission the whole day!? The pineapple thing looked interesting but we just got the meat and two eggs..I hate scrambled eggs, but I ate these for some reason. The pancakes were okay - nothing crazy special. The potatoes were yummy (But i love potatoes) and the turkey sausages were pretty good, they had an interesting rosemary-esque flavor which I liked! The best part of the entire meal was hands down the fresh orange and strawberry juice. GET IT. You will not be disappointed. I was astonished at how good it was.  Oh they charge you $2.00 if you are sharing..which is lame. 1 star off for that. And another for no reservations. another off for the unnecessary hype, and one on for the orange-strawberry juice!
Maybe it's that a Sunday morning breakfast here always has capped off a great weekend in Chicago, but this place is great!  I love spicy breakfast, and they have great options for that on the menu.
Can't wait to come back for more!  Bright cheery atmosphere, fast service, and pancakes that can't be beat!

Absolutely amazing breakfast chain. Delicious coffee, friendly & energetic staff, and just amazing food. The busy always seems to be bustling with a good amount of noise but I like that in the mornings to help me wake up. You have to find street parking but I've never had trouble. The interior decor is modern and retro which somehow helps to motivate me. Probably because I ate here on my business trip or maybe because my entire experience was psychologically deemed "the north" as compared to southern Texas. Nonetheless, this is a must stop every time I go to Chicago.

I'm a fan! I never enjoyed breakfast like this. Great food and service. No way could be compared to denny's or IHOP. I'm not a fan of vegetarian breakfast but the Cajun "Shroom Scrambler" is the Best. It has grilled portabello shroom and some mixed veggies on it. You'll be suprised for this breakfast dish. It's AMAZING! I recommend for everybody if you want a GREAT reasonably prized breakfast or even BRUNCH. Just be ready to line up the door because the place gets really packed specially if it falls on a weekend.

Definitely nothing special about this place.  We went here for a friend's birthday brunch.  We didn't have reservations, so it took about a half hour to be seated.  We parked at validated parking garage next door, which is only 2 hour parking, so this made for a very rushed meal. I had the smoked salmon; was not impressed.  The place was busy, so service was very slow.  Also, although the restaurant is BYOB, they did not let us use the OJ my friends had brought for mimosas, even though one friend - the birthday girl - told our waitress she had called ahead and gotten the ok for this :-(

I almost bumped it up to five stars, because it was pretty much as good as brunch can get.  But, I'll reserve 5-star breakfast for Cracker Barrel, and leave this with 4, because it didn't really have any distinctive ambiance to speak of.  It was certainly clean and bright and pleasant, but nothing unique. The food, however, was as good as it gets.  All dishes were around $10, and they were all more filling than anyone could handle.  And of course, they were delicious.  There's a great variety of unique omelettes, great classics like eggs benedict and french toast and pancakes, and my favorite: skillet meals.  The Countryside Skillet was just a huge skillet full of everything wonderful: sausage, ham, bacon, fried potatoes, peppers, onions, cheese, eggs, you name it.  Great hearty meal. Definitely a top notch breakfast/brunch spot.

This place had been on my radar since I moved to Chicago and I finally got to eat there, after waiting in line for about half an hour.  Is the food good?  Yes.  Is it worth the hype and the wait?  Probably not.  There are many other superb breakfast/brunch joints in Chicago to satisfy.  This is more of a tourist trap than anything else.  I had a tex-mex scramble or some such variation thereof.  It was good but I didn't die from pleasure while eating it.  The coffee is pretty tasty and you can get it in hazelnut, which is my favorite.   Our server was clearly bored with her job or maybe with life.  She wasn't very attentive or friendly.  I can sympathize with her working in the food service industry myself but if you want a good tip you better at least smile.  Sheesh.

Well prepared, solid diner food, but nothing special.  Our meals were tasty, but I was not impressed with the creativity of options or the service.  That being said, if you want all-American classic breakfast, this is a sure bet.  But, with all of the other brunch options in Chicago, there are many others that have more originality to offer.  It just doesn't stand out.

So I get a phone call at 6:30 AM this morning saying let's go to Yolk for breakfast.  Granted I usually don't get up until 10:30-11AM, everyday (I'm a rock star, ya'll didn't know).  Well, since I'm up now I might as well go, even though it's fifteen degrees outside.  Ok on to the restaurant.  Now considering breakfast is usually the cheapest meal of the day, someone please tell me why these new restaurant's are charging $5 for a bowl of oatmeal.  I mean come on, it's oatmeal.  That's like restaurant's that charges $15 for a tilipia dish. (Isn't tilipia one of the cheapest fishes you can buy)  Anyway, I order the oatmeal just because I want to see if I'll be transformed to some unknown land and never what to eat oatmeal from any other place because it is that good. (Kinda like I won't order crab cakes unless I'm close to an ocean). With that said, I'll go to Valois for my old school oatmeal that's $1.50. Seriously. So, I also order the Eggs Benedict which on the menu says that they're "the best in town". #crickets.  Yeah I really did hear crickets in my head. The Eggs Benedict were just ok. The hollandaise sauce didn't seem to have that much flavor. My friend order one of the skillets. I can't remember which one but it didn't look like anything different that what you would get at Denny's or any other place.  All in all, it's a nice place to go considering the ambience and waitstaff. Just a little over priced for breakfast in my opinion but I'll probably go back and try the pancakes or something but I'll wait for the summer because parking sucks and walking a block and a half in 15 degree weather also sucks. Yeah! I'm a little spoiled I'll admit it.  Oh! I was told the strawberry-orange juice was very good. I'm going back to bed now.

Delicious place for brunch! Highly recommend it! Apparently, it is BYOB as the table next to us was poppin' bottles. The wait was a bit long (30 mins), but it was definitely worth it! I ordered an egg-white california omelette with a side of pumpkin pancakes.The pancakes were even better though. Some of the most delicious pancakes I've ever had! They come topped with cranberries. The perfect breakfast treat during the holidays! You will not leave hungry. The price was reasonable and they definitely do serve huge portions here.
I really liked this place. Great food and good service. I had an omelet and it was huge! It was very good and I would return the next time I'm in the Chicago area.

I've thought long and hard about what I could complain about and there is nothing!  At most, I could say that the wait is long, but good things come to those that wait.  I would be suspicious if the wait wasn't long.  Actually, the wait wasn't that long, but would have seemed longer if the food sucked! Anyway, my wife and I have been on a breakfast spot search lately and this place was money.  A friend recommended but I didn't let my wife know that because last time he recommended a horrible place.  I'm all for second chances though and a good thing too. I had a countryside skillet.  It was meatastic.  They didn't have to put the country gravy on the side, but thank god that they did.  My wife had the peach cobbler crepe.   It was like having desert for breakfast and who doesn't like desert?!  You need to know what you are getting into before you order it though.  My wife says that it was TOO much food.  We did have the orange-strawberry juice and it was good enough to smack yo' momma!   While the word "yolk" sounds disgusting when you think about it, this resteraunt makes the word sound delicious once you have been there.  Yolk is hot like fire!

We ate at Yolk this morning and I am so glad we did. I was surprised how packed it was but we were seated right away. The decor was very modern. I ordered the bacon egg and cheese quesadilla. The coffee was good and the waitress made sure our cups were never empty. The only thing I would have liked more is if the milk came in a little serving cup instead of packets. My breakfast also came with diced potatoes which were very thick and tasty. The prices are just a tad higher than I would have liked to pay but the food, service, and cleanliness more than made up for that. I left stuffed. We even got to see Brian Urlacher eating breakfast before todays game.

Yolk on Michigan was such a cool place to be.  Not only was the food awesome, but seeing Chicago Bears Linebacker Brian Urlacher come in for breakfast at the same time made it that much cooler of an experience.   At first I thought the menu was a little pricey, but for the amount of food they give you its not bad at all.  I had a Crepe Combination, which gives you two delicious Crepe's of your choice (I had nutella with banana's and walnuts - so so good), eggs, bacon and sausage.  I can eat a lot, but I couldn't finish this meal.  Overall the service and atmosphere were great and I would definitely go back next time I come to Chicago.  Since we had walked there in the morning during a snow storm the streets were really quiet, but when we walked into this place it was packed wall to wall.  For so many people to go out of their way to eat here, that's telling you all you need to know.
Id come here everyday If i could for brunch or breakfast! :p Fun bright atmosphere, really close to the lake and yummy food! :) Must try the egg bagel and the pineapple parfait..yum yum yummm!! :) :)
Delicious combinations and multitude of options. Even their basic pancake exceeds expectation!

I live in the area.  Finally I got over to yolk for breakfast.  I went on a Thursday around 7 or 8 am.  It was not very busy at all.  This was nice because I have seen a pretty good wait walking by here on weekend mornings. I have the California omlette.  At least it had avocado involved (must be a CA omlette, right?)  I was very please.  Big healthy portion that will not leave you walking away hungry.  Price was also quite reasonable around $10.  The waiter never let my coffee empty and was more than attentive and kind.  I wouldn't recommend to friends.  It isn't anything too off the beaten path. P.S. They make muffins and various baked breakfast things fresh each day so go early and get them fresh :)

I found Yolk on my first trip to Chicago when I was looking for apartments here.  We ate here 3 out of the 4 days we were in town and a few months later moved into the neighborhood.  We've lived here more than 2 years now and it's still our favorite place for breakfast!  I've never been disappointed.  Try the multigrain pancakes you can get them on the side of most orders instead of toast, they are delicious!   If you are looking for a decadent seasonal treat, try the pumpkin swirl french toast.  We were recently given a sample of this and I haven't been able to stop thinking about it!  If you get there after 9am you're most likely gonna have a wait but trust me, it's worth it.

LOVE this place.  Have never had a bad breakfast here.  Service is friendly, efficient and very quick.  Food is consistently excellent.  Personal favorite is the Orange Bread French Toast, but there are plenty of choices to suit any palate.  The coffee is just okay -- could be a better bean and cups could be bigger.  Be prepared for a considerable wait during prime-time weekend mornings because this is obviously a popular neighborhood restaurant.

I got the Tour De France (french toast= banana nut, sweet orange, lemon poppy seed).  It was  good, but it wasn't what I expected.  The breads are kind of like the poundcakes that you get at Starbucks and then french toasted and topped with fruit and sauce.  It was  too sweet to finish, and while eating it i had to balance it with the Eggs Benedict (which I recommend).  The Tour De France is good if you want to try the 3 different flavors of french toast, but personally I only really liked the Lemon Poppy Seed.

Don't be swayed from the fact that this place looks very tiny from the outside. Once inside, you will realize it is huge. My only qualm, actually, is the fact that it looked like a cafeteria gone modern.  I had a steak skillette, of course, and the others at my table ordered a variety of things (try the nutella with strawberry crepes because they looked great).  The food was amazing and the total of 54 bucks for four people is not that bad considering you are in the city! The parking is only $7 because they validate your ticket.  You really can't go wrong with this place!

I'm torn between a 3 and a 4 star review. What I tried: California Omlette: FANTASTIC Coffee: AWFUL. WASTE OF TIME. (burnt, thin, & disgusting-read previous reviews for confirmation) Pecan Waffle: OK but too sweet Pancakes: Very good, nice and fluffy Eggs Benedict: Disappointing (esp if it's supposed to be best in town) Strawberry & Orange Juice: Not bad, but I've had better. Location: Convenient, walkable distance to Museum Campus Service: Standard Decor/Interior: Nice and modern. In Short: I'd go back for that omlette anyday. It was pretty darn good, but that was also the worst coffee ever.   (We asked for a refund, which we got)

Love, love, love the food here.  The wait is always long,  but is more than made up for by the cuisine.  I always have great company when I go.  And I always enjoy the food.  Been at least 6 times & consistently in love with this food. And I believe it's BYOB.  I haven't tested that theory, but I would love to with a bottle of champagne for mimosas!!!

Loved it!!! Ate breakfast here while visiting Chicago. We waited nearly 30 min for a seat and I see why. The food is fresh and delicious, I recommend the bacon and the pancakes were the best I've had. I'll definitely come here on my next visit to chitown.

I actually like this place a lot.  I went to the location on the south loop.  We were referred here by our doorman at Swissotel on Wacker.   I'm a HUGE breakfast fan and this is a breakfast joint so they get my most critical eye.  This place was great. The atmosphere was open and modern.  The kitchen was partially open so that you could see who was cooking your food.  They also had a lunch counter to sit and eat if you didn't want to wait for a table.  We ended up getting a booth.   It was crowded but we were seated almost right away (3 minute wait), and our waitress was busy but very attentive.  The clientele was the minivan driving set and also some who had obviously hit the club scene the night before and crawled out from under a beer box in search of hangover abating sustenance.    The menu was full of fresh fruit and tons of choices.  I ordered my standard pancakes, eggs scrambled with cheese and wheat toast.  My order came with fresh fruit, which is usually a huge side order charge at most places.  I ordered the strawberry orange juice which was super tasty and also some coffee, which they kept filled.  They had flavored creamers at every table in addition to non-dairy creamer.  They also had truvia and sugar in the raw which is a must. The pancakes are huge, taking up almost the entire plate.  Unfortunately I found the pancake batter to be a little too sweet for me.  IHOP is still hands down my favorite pancake joint.  The syrup was very good and served in little ceramic creamer pitchers.  The portions were huge and I didn't come anywhere close to eating my entire meal.  My dining partner was not as happy.  He loved the pancakes but had ordered 'The Works" omelette but found that there wasn't much meat in it.  He picked his omelette apart and ate only pieces of it.  The prices were a bit high for breakfast but probably typical for Chicago at around 10 per entree.  Food came out fast in probably about ten minutes. They also serve Crepes, Frittatas, Oatmeal, 5 different types of Eggs Benedict, Salads, Wraps and Burgers.  If they had this chain in the Detroit area I'd eat breakfast there every weekend.  If I could, I would rate 4.5/5 stars because if the pancakes had been like IHOPs it'd be a 5!

Pot Roast Eggs Benedict. Did that get your attention?  Because it should. Anywho, I think Yolk is pretty fantastic (forget going there on the weekends though, the line is out the door).  You get these monster servings, within minutes of ordering, by super speedy servers ... and the fruit garnishes are ACTUALLY FRESH! Just a great deal.

A friend suggested this when he heard I liked going out for breakfast.  The location was a great jumping off point to the museums and the food was abundant and tasty.  There was quite a line so we sat at the bar.  There was a wonderful array of food going by.  Despite the long lines, the wait wasn't too bad.

Stumbled in here on a Saturday morning after it was recommended by our concierge at the Blackstone. It was packed and we were hungry but the wait didn't take that long considering how many people were waiting.  The menu is large and filled with a number of great sounding options. We shard a glass of delicious orange strawberry juice- wow! That stuff is seriously good!  For breakfast, I went with a Garden Skillet to get all the veggie but added ham as well. Breakfast potatoes with scrambled eggs and tons of veggies(+ham) came out and I was in love!  My sis had a bacon quesadilla which looked more like a burrito but tasted great. We also couldnt resist splitting a multi-grain pancake. HOlY COW those are tasty!  We came back for breakfast again before our trip ended. THis time I had a veggie omlette, and again added ham. It was HUGE and perfectly done. Loved every bite. Sis tried Some savory crepes that were superb. They had egg an avocado and were the perfect mix of sweet and savory. The multi-grain pancake was, once again, a delightful cap to a self-indulgent gastronomic splurge!
My first time there and boy was it packed! We did get seated really quickly though unlike some of the groups after us. Very clean establishment and the pancakes and hash were good!

I was really hesitant to go.... breakfast food has been such a disappointment lately for me. To my surprise... I recommend!!! Parking sucks. There's a garage right next door and Yolk will validate it so that it's $7 instead of $9.  Must get: strawberry orange juice. Very delicious. Can't think of any other spot that has something similar. I got the Zamboni crepes: ham, spinach, hollandaise sauce, scrambled eggs, and i'm sure something else..... =) i added mushrooms. Cuz I'm a mushroom junkie. I really liked it! The crepes were fluffy. Not flat or super delicate. But almost meat-y! But still sweet and light. No sogginess here. The potatoes that came with it are also really good too. Flavored, good on texture, good on salt.  Just the portions are HUGE!! Came with two crepes.  I finished only about 3/4 of one and got full. My bf got somethin else. Can't remember. I was too interested in mine.  But there are definitely a lot of things that look real interesting on the menu, So I'll definitely be back for more.

Word to the wise... 1.  Don't order the coffee.  Burnt. Watered down.  Not worth your $2.34. 2.  Know what you want to order ASAP.  They are almost always extremely busy and you'll be lucky to get your servers attention more than just to order and get your check. 3.  Be good to your heart.  Get egg whites or Egg Beaters...no extra charge! 4.  Don't forget to pick up a chocolate covered dinner mint at the cash register!

Always crowded and loud on the weekends, but if you're patient enough, look forward to tasty coffee and  whole multi-grain pancakes.  Actually some of the best I've had.  Nice variety of fresh fruit (pineapple, strawberries, melon) and veggie selection. The skillet had good potatoes, not as oily or fried as most, however I prefer veggie volume.  No silly charge for egg whites.  Vegetarian options and lots of variety on the menu. I'd like to go back and try some of the sea food options . Lunch menu is also enticing.

Mmmph brunch is the best meal of the day. Yolk has some big portions.  I purposely took a convoluted path to the bathroom so I could walk around and spy on people's food.  I got the TUSCAN FRITTATA and it was delish and covered in goat cheese (even better).  Definitely spring for a glass of STRAWBERRY ORANGE JUICE and try not to chug it because it's so good.   If you get an omelet, be warned they are are football-sized. My only criticism is I feel that a nice place like this should have better jam and butter instead of the kind you get on an airplane.

I can ride my bike to the restaurant, as they have a bike rack out front.  always a plus.  If you are by yourself, you can almost always get immediate seating at the bar.   I've been there for breakfast twice, and both times I have been very impressed.  A great experience all around.
Really good spot for breakfest. On a weekend you may want to try to get there before 9am (the lines are pretty long after). Service was quick and the atmosphere is high energy and diverse crowd.

First, I don't think the wait is ever worth it. If you are going to attempt to go for weekend brunch, go with a small group and opt to sit at the counter if possible.  Our waitress managed to mess up my order- Chocolate Chip pancakes. They're on the menu, I didn't make any special requests or anything, and she brought out plain ones like I had ordered them a la carte. Really? And they weren't that impressive. A little over priced as well.  I'd take your chances somewhere else.

Fantastically awesome brunch place!  My friend and I were visiting and decided to hit up Yolk before heading to the Field Museum. Yes, the wait was a bit long- but totally worth it. It would be nice if they had more seating in the waiting area (like benches along the walls of the side room).  I had the "Tour de France" dish and it was delicious. Three types of bread used for french toast with three different toppings. I also had a bit of my friend's peach crepes, which were equally yummy.  All in all, a great time.

EHHH... There are far better brunch places in the city, I don't get why Yolk gets a lot of hype. My theory is that there are so few in the loop/south loop area, and in that area where there are lots of hotels and touristy parks and colleges, people hit up Yolk because its nearby. Seriously people, its just overpriced breakfast after a long wait and they wanna rush you out the door afterwards... but make you wait for centuries to get you your check. What kind of brunch is that?  Not a fan.

Did you know? Yolk has new twists on egg benedict.. Like chorizo, florentine, etc. Best breakfast in the city. The ambiance is really nice. Its just your neighborhood bfast bar with great food. Yes, the wait is always long on the weekend, but its def worth it. Why else do you think ppl still stick around for an hour? Theyre no ordinary eggs benny. I would def rec getting a cup of strawberry orange juice as its the best ive ever had. Its my favorite.

It is SO hard to review Yolk, after having been a few times and not had a wait, and then coming back and having an hour wait, and an overall iffy experience. So I will go based off my meal this past weekend with a group of my (very picky) girlfriends.  We waited on a Saturday morning for about 45 minutes to an hour for a table for four.  The waiting area accommodated the majority of the people who wanted to be inside, so that was nice.  We finally sat down. Ordered coffee, juice, and water and the drinks were brought immediately to the table.  We ordered. I ordered an omelet, two of my friends ordered a make your own skillet, and the other ordered the veggie skillet.  My omelet was good and the potatoes were yummy as well.  One of my friends food was prepared wrong, so she sent it back.  YIKES...  Put picky girls together and you get a table of unhappy people. Yolk has great food, but waiting on it isn't as great.

Yolk.  It's the best part of the egg. The interior of the restaurant is deceptively bigger than it looks from the outside.  Plus.  The long line (many runners/walkers from the Susan G. Komen race, like us, this past Sat.) of customers was handled expertly, and our group of 6 didn't have to wait as long as expected.   I ordered the irish benny eggs benedict (it has corned beef hash on it).  I would have liked the hash to have been crisper and way less salty.  Get your belly ready because the portions are hefty!  Great coffee and coffee service.

Two words: Irish Benny.  This savory delight is a eggs benedict with corned beef hash.  Holy. Snap. Good.  Probably the best breakfast dish I have ever eaten.  The food selection is awesome, lots of different things to choose from. The wait is usually pretty significant if you go on weekend mornings, but it really isn't that bad if the weather is nice, otherwise, there isn't that large of a place for the throngs to wait. Negatives: I don't care for the coffee they have here, the restaurant is OMG loud with all those people in there, and the service can be pokey with so many people in there.

Good, solid choice for your brunching needs as they have a mighty big selection.  The service was fine and the food is good.  I'm just not really in love with the place as I thought I should be...maybe it's b/c there are no bloody mary's or mimosas?  And I feel like it's a bit pricey...or am I just cheap? I dunno...but it's not far from me and it's cozy and does the job. But that wait is insane.  And it always is on the weekends.  They are obviously doing something right and I'm still a fan...I just don't frequent it as I hate waiting and there's nothing I crave to justify that wait. Weekdays are def better for this spot.
Always delicious and worth the wait. Bacon waffles are the bomb and so is the steak skillet.

Great food, poor service.  I go to Yolk in the early weekday mornings to avoid the weekend rush.  Lately I feel like I'm continually touching the hot stove with the service.   Usually there are no more than 8 patrons there when I go so you'd think service would be exceptional! Wrong.  You're lucky to get a coffee refill.  The wait staff tends to be more engaged with their personal conversations at the bar rather than occasionally checking on the customers.  I went my entire meal, read the paper, and sat at my booth for 10 minutes waiting for the check without seeing the waitress again.  This isn't an isolated inncident either.  It's usually not that bad but still way below par. The wait staff is the face of your restaurant.  The food is great but service like that has me leaving annoyed enough to write a poor review on Yelp.

I've heard about Yolk several times, and finally decided to get in line and try it. Yolk certainly does not live up to its hype. You'll wait in line at Yolk for 20-50 minutes before being seated, unless you go on a weekday, and even then, it's crowded. Nearly all of Yolk's customers are tourists staying at nearby hotels, so there are lots of big groups and families. The decor is completely forgettable, and the noise is deafening. I didn't find the waitstaff particularly friendly or helpful. If anything, our waitress seemed to have more important things to do than refill our water glasses or ask if we needed anything. Sure, Yolk has an expansive menu with plenty of interesting sounding options, but the food itself is what you would find at Denny's under another name. Perhaps I'm too harsh - my companion said it was "decent." And yes, the portions are huge - probably too big in all honesty. Either way, it is not the best brunch you'll ever have. I'd suggest Bongo Room or Elate over Yolk any day.

This is a ridiculous wait for breakfast. Their PA system is terrible and several tables missed their names while we were there.  I would recommend going to a different restaurant in a different neighborhood for breakfast over ever recommending this place, although the food is very good.

Breakfast is my favorite meal to go out for, and this was great. I have been there a few times and have had a great experience every time. They have so much to choose from it was hard to decide what to get. We did allot of sharing at our table. Every thing I have had there I would have again.

I am drooling as I write this review. My family and I stopped here when we were in Chicago for the day moving my cousin into her college . Upon arriving at the restaurant, there were tons of people waiting outside to be called for a table. We went inside and gave our names. We were told that it would be a 30 minute wait. We decided to wait.  It was far less than 30 minutes, perhaps more like 15. We were seated and had the best waiter ( I am sorry I forgot your name sweetie). The menu is huge. But not overwhelming! There are many many options to chose from! I asked him his opinion on which he preferred, the Belgian waffle or nutella crepe. He suggested the crepe and I went for it.   Oh my goodness. It was an orgasm in my mouth! The Nutella crepe was to die for! The crepe was covered with bananas and strawberries and powdered sugar and chocolate and whipped cream. This is to die for! I can't wait to go back to Chicago and order the crepe again!
Best breakfast place!  Yes there is a wait especailly on the weekends, but it's well worth it!  I go there just about every weekend and still haven't had the same thing twice!

My friend and I were visiting Chicago and wanted one last meal before our flight back to LA. We decided to try Yolk and we were very pleased with the portion and taste of our food. He ordered a salmon combo with a side of apple cinnamon pancakes and I ordered banana crepes with strawberries on the side. The ingredients were fresh and the food was cooked perfectly. What won my heart though was the fact that the bananas and apples were freshly cooked; as oppose to being processed and drenched in syrup like many breakfast spots. Overall, I think Yolk is a good balance between diner style breakfast and your french inspired- new American brunch cafe.

I miss Yolk more now that no such brunch place exists in New York. The egg selections are unending and all worth trying. Personally, I'm a big fan of their skillets. Yolk is what brunch is meant to be.

Always a great morning start. Came here on Friday morning, no wait, quick service, no muss, no fuss, good food. I come here regularly when I have time for sit down breakfast but twice now I found a dirty coffee mug. No big deal but please do some quality check before you place the table setting. Other than that food is consistently good and love that you give a substantial side of fruit! Maybe you should think of opening for dinner, heh?

Enough reviews here, as I always say. If I had to emphasize one thing about this place, the portions are HUGE!  If you're not a typical midwesterner, you will not be able to finish your dish. Speaking for breakfast, which I do have the first-hand account.

Their portions are more appropriate for a moose than for a human. This would be awesome if only it was good. Instead, its just kind like the breakfast food served at every normal, mediocre, average diner and breakfast place across America. It looks different. It feels different. And you'll want it to be different. But its not. Rather, its just a lot more of the same old stuff piled high on a huge plate. If that's your thing, enjroix (fake French for enjoy).

Took a vacation to Chicago and this was my first stop.  The boyfriend and I arrived at our hotel (The Blackstone...wonderful!) at about 10am and were starving for a big breakfast.  The concierge at the hotel directed us to Yolk as it was just a few blocks away.  Thank you concierge!  We were not disappointed.  I had the South-of-the-Border Benny which is a Mexican twist on the traditional eggs benedict (my fave).  It was absolutely perfect.  My boyfriend made his own omelet, which we swore had to be about 5 eggs, but the waiter claimed only 2..yeah right  ;')  The big portions are fun, the atmosphere is nice, decent coffee, good price range.  The wait staff was very friendly and attentive; it wasn't too busy on a Thursday morning though.  I would definitely be excited to go back next time I'm in Chicago.

Been there twice lately, once on a Saturday morning, the other on a Sunday morning.  I understand that it is the busiest time and all, so I came prepared for a wait.  On the Saturday, it was also Lolla weekend, so the wait was close to an hour and half for two people.  During the wait, J and I split a cinnamon roll to tide over our hunger- it was good, wish it was warm and gooey though.  The Sunday brunch, it was only 20 minutes.  I got the spinach florentine benedict- it was good, it came with fruit and potatoes- average.  Got a side of corn beef hash- below average.  The next time I went, I got the crepes combo.  Came with sausage, bacon, and eggs.  The crepes were good, it came plain, but I wanted some strawberries on it.  It was not worth $2 for a few slices of strawberries though- it should have been smothered in it!  I found out later that I could have "upgraded" to a specialty crepe for the exact same price of the few slices of strawberries!  Oh well.  It takes a bit long to get food, both times, the table next to us got their food first, even though we ordered first... no biggie, not the servers fault, its the kitchen.  Must be something we ordered.  Overall, a good place to eat, just a little expensive $40 for brunch for two people (with sides and add ons).

Yolk is a great brunch spot. Their menu has quite the selection and the portions are big enough that I am sure everyone will be satisfied by the end of your meal. I got the pecan chicken salad.
